{{Italic title}} The '''''Accounting Historians Journal''''' is a biannual [[peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] published by the [[Academy of Accounting Historians]]. It is abstracted and indexed in [[Scopus]].<ref name=Scopus>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.com/online-tools/scopus/content-overview |title=Content overview |publisher=[[Elsevier]] |work=Scopus |accessdate=2015-08-18}}</ref> The journal was established in 1977, as a successor of "The Accounting Historian", a quarterly newsletter published by the Academy of Accounting Historians between 1974 and 1976. The original newsletters were collected and published in 1981 as volumes 1 to 3 of the ''Accounting Historians Journal''.<ref>{{cite journal | authorlink1 = Edward N. Coffman | first1 = Edward N. | last1 = Coffman | authorlink2 = Mervyn W. Wingfield | first2 = Mervyn W. | last2 = Wingfield | url = http://umiss.lib.olemiss.edu:82/record=b1000774| jstor = 40691028 | title = Preface to Volume 1 | journal = Accounting Historians Journal | volume = 1 | issue = 1/4 | date = January–October 1974 }}</ref>
== References == <references/>
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.aahhq.org/AHJ}}

{{Infobox person | name = Adolf H. Lundin | other_names = | image = | caption = | birth_name = Adolf Henrik Lundin | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|12|19|df=y}} | birth_place = Sweden | death_date = {{death date and age|2006|9|30|1932|12|19|df=y}} | death_place = [[Geneva]], Switzerland | death_cause = [[leukemia]] | alma_mater = [[Royal Institute of Technology]]
[[International Institute for Management Development]] | occupation = Oil and mining entrepreneur | title = | known_for = founding [[Lundin Mining]] and [[Lundin Petroleum]] | salary = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = Eva Wehtje | children = 4 including [[Lukas Lundin]]
[[Ian Lundin]] | relations = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Adolf Henrik Lundin''', (19 December 1932 – 30 September 2006),{{cite news |url=http://www.dn.se/ekonomi/oljemagnaten-adolf-lundin-ar-dod |title=Oljemagnaten Adolf Lundin är död |publisher=Dagens Nyheter |first=Anders |last=Hellberg |date=September 30, 2006|language=sv}} was a Swedish oil and mining entrepreneur. From the 1970s through the 1990s Lundin established numerous natural resource companies both in the mining sector and the oil and gas sector, which in turn made a number of world class discoveries in the Middle East, Africa, Europe and South America. Several of these deposits are still producing commercial quantities of oil, gas, gold, copper and other minerals; others are still under development. Lundin made a fortune in the 1970s when he came across huge natural gas fields in Qatar. ==Biography== ===Early years=== Adolf Lundin earned a master's degree in 1956 from the [[Royal Institute of Technology]] in [[Stockholm]]. Between 1957 and 1960 he worked as a Petroleum Engineer for the [[Royal Dutch Shell|Royal Dutch Shell Group]] in South America. In 1961 he earned an [[MBA]] degree from the [[International Institute for Management Development|Centre d’Etudes Industrielles]] in [[Geneva]], Switzerland. Between 1961 and 1966 he was responsible for oil exploration activities in the [[North Sea]] and [[Portugal]] for the [[Nordstjernan|Ax:son Johnson Group]]. In 1966, he moved with his family to Geneva to work as assistant director of the Centre d’Etudes Industrielles (which later became the International Institute for Management Development). Adolf's brother Bertil (1946-2005) was head of the [[Kontoret för Särskild Inhämtning]] (The Office for Special Collection). The KSI is Sweden's most secretive intelligence agency. ==Career== In 1971, he started his career as an independent oil and mining entrepreneur on a global scale. His first successful venture was [[Gulfstream Resources]] which, in 1976, co-discovered the [[North Gas Field]], offshore [[Qatar]] - this field remains today as the single largest known gas accumulation in the world. Lundin was an ardent [[anti-Communist]]. In the United States Lundin was involved with the right-wing think tank, [[The Heritage Foundation]] based in Washington, D.C. ([[Reagan Doctrine]]/ [[Kirkpatrick Doctrine]]). In 1980, Lundin sponsored [[Ronald Reagan]]'s [[Ronald Reagan presidential campaign, 1980|election campaign]]. Lundin and his wife Eva were invited to the Reagent inauguration in 1981. The program included an inauguration party with [[Frank Sinatra]] that the couple watched from the front row.[https://www.thelocal.se/20111222/38102 ''Lundin may have led Bildt to the heart of darkness''], [[The Local]], 22 December 2011 He founded [[Lundin Mining]] in 1994.[http://www.lundinmining.com/s/History.asp Company History] Lunding mining. Investors In 1998, he was named ''[[International Swede of the Year]]'' by [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|His Majesty the King of Sweden]]. In 1999, Lundin Oil, made a major discovery of oil in the [[Thar Jath]] structure in an area in Sudan ([[Block 5A, South Sudan|Block 5A]]).[https://www.thelocal.se/20161128/swedish-oil-bosses-quizzed-in-human-rights-probe-lundin-sudan Swedish oil bosses quizzed in six-year human rights probe]. The Local, 28 November 2016 In 2000, Lundin invited the former prime minister (1991-1994) and EU envoy to the Balkans (1995) [[Carl Bildt]] to join his board of directors. In 2001 Lundin founded [[Lundin Petroleum]]. In 2002, he received an honorary doctorate from [[Georgi Plekhanov|Plekhanov]] [[Russian Academy of Economics]] in [[Moscow]]. He became the honorary chairman of [[Lundin Petroleum AB]], the chairman of [[Vostok Nafta Investment Ltd]] and a director of [[North Atlantic Natural Resources AB]], [[Atacama Minerals Corp.]], [[Champion Resources Inc.]], [[South Atlantic Ventures Ltd]], [[Tenke Mining Corp.]] and [[Valkyries Petroleum Corp.]] Adolf Lundin died in 2006, aged 73, from [[leukemia]]. He was survived by his wife, Eva Wehtje, whom he married in 1957, and their four children. His Lundin Group, continued by his sons Lukas and Ian Lundin. They have invested considerable resources in rebranding the Lundin Group to make it more socially acceptable. They started a philanthropic operation, "Lundin for Africa Foundation", and proclaimed in 2007 to donate $100 million to the [[Clinton Foundation]].[https://www.clintonfoundation.org/main/news-and-media/press-releases-and-statements/press-release-lundin-group-commits-100-million-to-clinton-giustra-sustainable-gr.html Lundin Group Commits $100 Million to Clinton Giustra Sustainable Growth Initiative], 6 Jule 2007 == Books == *Adolf H. Lundin: Biography by ULF Lundin Petroleum Giraffetink *Kirsten Lundell: Business in Blood and Oil: Lundin Petroleum in Africa, 2010 ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lundin, Adolf H.}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from leukemia]] [[Category:People from Geneva]] [[Category:Royal Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Switzerland]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Lundin family]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}}{{Use South African English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific_prefix = | name = Andrew Feinstein | honorific_suffix = | image = Andrew Feinstein.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = Feinstein at the presentation of the documentary "Shadow World: Inside the Global Arms Trade" in Copenhagen 2016 | order = | office = [[Member of the National Assembly of South Africa]] | term_start = 1994 | term_end = 2001 <!-- Personal life --> | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|3|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Cape Town]], South Africa | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship = South Africa | nationality = | party = [[African National Congress]] | otherparty = <!--For additional political affiliations--> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | spouse = {{marriage|Simone Sultana|1993}} | partner = <!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> | relations = | children = Three | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | relatives = | residence = [[London]], England | education = | alma_mater = {{plain list| * [[King's College, Cambridge]] * [[University of California, Berkeley]] * [[University of Cape Town]] }} | occupation = | profession = | known_for = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | awards = }} '''Andrew Josef Feinstein''' (born 16 March 1964) is a former [[South African]] politician who currently resides in the [[United Kingdom]], but remains a South African citizen.
==Personal life== He was born in [[Cape Town]] to Ralph Josef Feinstein and Erika Hemmer. He graduated from [[Wynberg Boys' High School]] in 1981, and received further education at [[King's College, Cambridge]], the [[University of California at Berkeley]] and the [[University of Cape Town]]. He married Simone Sultana on 18 December 1993, and has a son and a daughter. His interests include reading, classical & jazz music, cinema, theatre, watching rugby, cricket & soccer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whoswhosa.co.za/andrew-feinstein-3673|title=Andrew Feinstein {{!}} Who's Who SA|website=www.whoswhosa.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-01-03}}</ref>
==Political life== A member of the [[African National Congress]] (ANC), his political life began when he served as an advisor to [[Gauteng]]'s then-MEC of Finance, [[Jabu Moleketi]], from 1994 to 1996. He also worked as an economic advisor to then-premier [[Tokyo Sexwale]]. He was elected as a member of the [[Parliament of South Africa|South African Parliament]]'s [[National Assembly of South Africa|lower house]] in 1997.
During his time in office, he served as chair of its study group on public accounts and ANC's official spokesman on the [[National Assembly of South Africa|National Assembly]]'s public accounts committee. Feinstein was at the time referred to as "one of its most vocal and talented MPs", who argued that a thorough investigation into the [[South African Arms Deal]] had to be done.<ref>[http://70.84.171.10/~etools/newsbrief/2001/news0130.txt ''ANC seeks to play down Feinstein demotion'', SAPA, 29 February 2001.]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, he resigned in 2001 when the ANC refused to launch an investigation into the matter.<ref>[http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/pr/2001/pr0830c.html ''Statement by Andrew Feinstein MP'' - 30 August 2001] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090323082152/http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/pr/2001/pr0830c.html |date=23 March 2009 }}</ref> He was succeeded by [[Geoff Doidge]] in both positions.
==Immigration to the UK== He now resides in [[London]], where he chairs the Aids charity Friends of the [[Treatment Action Campaign]], and lectures and writes on South Africa. He also works as a Securities Coordinator for [[Investec Bank]] UK Ltd.
He is now considered an ANC dissident and critic, with his memoirs, ''After the Party'', being severely critical of the political culture of the ANC.
In an interview with ''[[Democracy Now!]]'', he noted the ways in which the global arms trade was linked to the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2012/12/26/as_us_faces_gun_epidemic_post |title=As U.S. Faces Gun Epidemic Post-Newtown, Obama Urged to Break With NRA & Back Global U.N. Arms Treaty |date=26 December 2012}}</ref>
In 2011 Feinstein published ''The Shadow World'', an investigation into the global [[arms industry]]. He reported "that the [[Arms industry|trade in weapons]] accounts for around 40 percent of all corruption in all world trade The .. trade in weapons is extremely closely tied into the mechanics of government. The defence manufacturers, those who make the weapons, are closely tied in to governments, to militaries, to intelligence agencies and crucially to political parties."<ref>{{cite news |title= Is society inherently corrupt? A look at the global arms industry and the effect corruption has on our politics, society and culture. |author= South to North |url= http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/south2north/2013/01/2013118151914861779.html |newspaper= Al Jazeera English |publisher= Al Jazeera |accessdate= 19 January 2013 }}</ref>
==Books== *''After the Party: A Personal and Political Journey Inside the ANC''<ref name="Feinstein2007">{{cite book|author=Andrew Feinstein|title=After the party: a personal and political journey inside the ANC|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xvgVAQAAIAAJ|year=2007|publisher=Jonathan Ball|isbn=978-1-86842-262-3}}</ref> *''The Shadow World: Inside the Global Arms Trade.''<ref name="Feinstein2011">{{cite book|author=Andrew Feinstein|title=The Shadow World: Inside the Global Arms Trade|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u06m3epox7wC|year=2011|publisher=Hamish Hamilton|isbn=978-0-241-14441-1}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/profile/andrewfeinstein Profile of and editorials by Feinstein] on [[The Guardian]]
{{Authority control}}

{{advert|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{infobox newspaper |name = Asian Private Banker |logo = Asian-Private-Banker Logo.png |image = |caption = |type = Trade publication |format = Website and newsletter |founder = Andrew Shale |editor = Sebastian Enberg (2016 - ) Shruti Advani (2009 - 2016) |foundation = 2009 |language = [[English language|English]] |headquarters = |sister newspapers = |ISSN = 2076-5320 |website = http://asianprivatebanker.com |owner = Key Positioning Limited | Caption = The cover of Asian Private Banker Magazine, Issue 97 | Image = [[File:Latest cover.jpg]] }} '''''Asian Private Banker''''' is an Asia-based intelligence, data and connections company which focuses on Asia's private wealth management communities.
==History== Asian Private Banker was founded in November 2009.
The region’s first event to focus on the private banking advisory community, ''Asian Private Banker''’s Investment Advisory Summit, was held in Hong Kong in June 2010. It led to a sister event in Singapore in October 2010, and the two events have since been held annually. Asian Private Banker was also the first to hold the Fund Selection Nexus in Hong Kong in 2012, followed by its sister event in Singapore – those events are also held annually. A number of industry functions and thought-leadership events are now hosted by Asian Private Banker.
Asian Private Banker released its first Asia AUM (Assets Under Management) League Table for the top 20 private banks in Asia in April 2012, followed by the Asia RM (Relationship Managers) Headcount League Table. These league tables are updated annually (in March) and are a result of investigative journalism and data collation. Asian Private Banker’s AUM and RM League Tables are used by mainstream financial media (Bloomberg,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-15/deutsche-bank-looking-to-grow-asia-wealth-unit-with-new-hires|title=Deutsche Bank Looking to Grow Asia Wealth Unit With New Hires|last=Chanjaroen|first=Chanyaporn|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref> Financial Times,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/e2818d30-012c-11e6-ac98-3c15a1aa2e62.html#axzz45mHLWmXA|title=JPMorgan cuts 20% of relationship managers at Asia private bank|last=Weinland|first=Don|date=2016-04-13|last2=Hughes|first2=Jennifer|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref> Reuters,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-barclays-ocbc-wealth-idUSKCN0X400H|title=OCBC grabs Barclays Asia wealth business after poaching concerns spook rival|date=2016-04-07|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref> The Business Times<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/stocks/ocbc-pays-us320m-cash-for-barclays-private-bank-business-in-singapore-hk|title=OCBC pays US$320m cash for Barclays' private bank business in Singapore, HK|last=Sen|first=Siow Li|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref>).
Asian Private Banker’s first Awards for Distinction was held in 2011. The Awards Gala Dinner, held in February each year, is a gathering of figures in Asia’s private banking community.
==Audience== [[File:First Issue.jpg|thumb|The cover of the first issue of Asian Private Banker magazine]] The magazine and website are aimed at relationship managers, C-suite management at private banks, and specialists in charge of product selection. The majority of the readership is based in the two main off-shore booking centres: Hong Kong and Singapore, with a smaller following in China, the UK, Switzerland, and the US.
==Content== ===Digital=== The website provides daily digital content and news articles, as well as an archive of previously published content. Asian Private Banker also publishes yearly the Asia and India AUM and RM Headcount League Tables on the website, detailing the assets under management and relationship managers headcount of the leading private banks in Asia, which is updated quarterly, and cited as a source by other industry-leading publications, such as Bloomberg,<ref>{{cite web|title=Citi's assets climb to 251 billion|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-06-24/citigroup-s-asian-wealth-management-assets-climb-to-251-billion|publisher= Bloomberg|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> and the Financial Times.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asia’s self-made entrepreneurs stoke growth in private banking assets|url= http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/ecc4523a-ea79-11e3-8dde-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3UjHAfK78|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref>
===Print=== A print magazine is published monthly. It comprises a lead features article on industry issues, regular columns and a compilation of articles from the website during that period.
===Data and research=== The Asian Private Banker AUM (assets under management) and RM (relationship managers) League Tables are cited by industry sources as the most reliable of their kind,<ref>{{cite web|title=Asia's wealth spurs competition for private bankers: Citi|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/18/us-wealth-summit-citigroup-idUSKBN0ET23120140618|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=18 June 2014}}</ref> and the magazine is now using its network within the industry to build its data offering.
==Events== Asian Private Banker hosts a number of industry functions and thought-leadership events in Asia.
=== Alternatives Selection Nexus (ASN) === Half-day panel discussions and product pitching workshops for private bank and IAM selectors who decide which alternatives products are put forward to clients, ICs and RMs, plus specific family offices who invest in alternatives. The first ASN events were held in April 2017 in Hong Kong and Singapore.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/asn/]
=== Chief Operating Officers Leaders Conversation (COOLC) === Half-day leaders discussion and intimate roundtable conversations between COOs, CTOs and CDOs around their respective private bank's technology and innovation agendas. The first COOLC events were held in November 2015 in Singapore.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/coolc/]
=== Discretionary Portfolio Management Leaders Conversation (DPMLC) === Half-day panel discussions and pitching workshops where DPM leaders from private banks discuss, debate and study new products for their DPM allocation, and examine other issues affecting DPM traction in Asia. The first DPMLC event was held in December 2015 in Singapore.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/dpmlc/]
=== Discretionary Dialogue === Half-day thematic leaders discussion and intimate roundtable conversation for between the key discretionary leaders and gatekeepers at the private banks. The first events were held in September 2017 in Hong Kong and Singapore.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/dpmd/]
===Fund Selection Nexus===
The first fund selector function in Asia. The first event was held in 2012. Half-day panel discussions and pitching workshops for fund selection team leaders, IAM/MFO selectors and select family offices.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/fsn/]
=== IAM and Family Office Leaders Conversation (IFLC) === Half-day leaders discussion and intimate and roundtable conversations where C-suite IAM leadership and single family offices gather to examine the industry’s development, innovative products and future expansion plans.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/iflc/]
===Investment Advisory Summit (IAS)===
Beginning in 2010, the Investment Advisory Summits (IAS) are events held in Asia that address the needs and issues facing the heads of advisory, heads of investment and senior RMs at Asia’s private banks. Each summit in Singapore and Hong Kong involves over 250 participants.[https://asianprivatebanker.com/events/ias/]
=== RM Nexus === RM Nexus functions are designed and built for senior Asia-based Relationship Managers.
The RM Nexus function is a cross-bank gathering, driven by the RM’s themselves, of 80 self-selected senior RM’s (per location) who are interested in understanding more about UL and the changing needs of Asian clients.
==Awards==
====Awards for Distinction==== Beginning in 2011, the Awards for Distinction are awarded to the private banks in February through a qualitative and quantitative point-based system by Asian Private Banker’s judging panel. The private banks who exhibit adaptability in a constantly changing industry, proficiency in the craft of private banking, and attentiveness to client needs are most qualified to win.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.media-outreach.com/release.php/View/2016/Asian-Private-Banker-(APB)-Awards-for-Distinction-(AFD)-2015:-Credit-Suisse-Wins-Best-Private-Bank---Asia.html|title=Asian Private Banker (APB) Awards for Distinction (AFD) 2015: Credit Suisse Wins Best Private Bank - Asia {{!}} Media Outreach|website=www.media-outreach.com|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.credit-suisse.com/hk/en/about-us/our-company/awards.html|title=Awards|website=Credit Suisse|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref>
====Structured Products Awards for Excellence==== Asian Private Banker’s Structured Products Awards for Excellence celebrate the accomplishments of providers of structured products to the region’s private banking and wealth management clients. It is now in its sixth year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.societegenerale.asia/en/newsroom/awards/awards-details/news/asia-private-banker-structured-products-awards-for-excellence-2015/|title=Asia Private Banker - Structured Products Awards for Excellence 2015|website=Société Générale|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref>
==== Asset Management Awards for Excellence ==== The Asset Management Poll records the votes and opinions of key stakeholders at Asia’s private banks in funds due diligence and advisory with regards to asset managers and funds service providers. These awards are based on extensive polling and interviews with buy-side private banking selectors.
In 2016, 36 fund selection teams<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpmorganam.com.hk/jpm/am/en/funds/awards|title=Fund Awards {{!}} J.P. Morgan Asset Management|website=www.jpmorganam.com.hk|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cib.societegenerale.com/en/supporting-the-economy/awards-rankings/awards-ranking/news/asian-private-banker-asset-management-awards-for-excellence-2016/|title=Asian Private Banker Asset Management Awards for Excellence 2016|website=Société Générale|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref> at 28 private banks in Hong Kong and Singapore where polled for the Asset Management Awards for Excellence.
==== Technology Awards ==== The Asian Private Banker Technology Awards are awarded to the tech industry’s most innovative, successful and relevant technology solutions and providers for Asia’s private banking and wealth management industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://enterprise.microsoft.com/en-us/industries/banking-and-capital-markets/leading-the-way-in-asian-banking-technology/|title=Leading the way in Asian banking technology - Microsoft Enterprise|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref>

{{other uses}} {{Infobox road |name= Bay Street |image=Bay Street May 2010.jpg |image_notes= Bay Street looking towards [[Old City Hall (Toronto)|Old City Hall]], its [[terminating vista]] south of Queen Street |maint= |marker_image=[[File:BayStreetSign.jpg|190px]] |established= |length_km= |map=Bay St map.png |length_ref= |direction_a=North |direction_b=South |cities= [[Toronto]] |terminus_a= [[Davenport Road]] |junction= |terminus_b = [[Lake Ontario]] |browse= {{on-exp browse |title=Nearby arterial roads |next_link= [[Yonge Street]] |route= Bay Street |previous_link = [[University Avenue (Toronto)|University Avenue]], [[Avenue Road]]}} }}
[[File:Rushing.jpg|thumb|The intersection of Bay Street and [[King Street (Toronto)|King Street]] is considered the heart of Canada's financial industry]] [[File:BayStreetCanyon.jpg|thumb|Bay Street highrise canyon looking north from Elm Street]] '''Bay Street''' is a major thoroughfare in [[Downtown Toronto|Downtown]] [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. It is the centre of [[Toronto]]'s [[Financial District, Toronto|Financial District]] and is often used by [[metonymy]] to refer to [[Economy of Canada|Canada's financial services industry]] since succeeding [[Montreal]]'s [[Saint Jacques Street|St. James Street]] in that role in the 1970s.
Bay Street begins at [[Queens Quay (Toronto)|Queens Quay]] ([[Toronto Harbour]]) in the south and ends at Davenport Road in the north. The original section of Bay Street ran only as far north as [[Queen Street West]]. Sections north of Queen Street were renamed Bay Street as several other streets were consolidated and several gaps filled in to create a new thoroughfare in the 1920s. The largest of these streets, Terauley Street, ran from Queen Street West to Grenville Street. At these two points, there is a curve in Bay Street.
"Bay Street" is frequently used as a metonym to refer to Toronto's Financial District and the Canadian financial sector as a whole, similar to [[Wall Street]] in the United States. "Bay Street banker", as in the phrase "cold as a Bay Street banker's heart", was a term of opprobrium especially among Prairie farmers who feared that Toronto-based financial interests were hurting them.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Eric Partridge|author2=Tom Dalzell|author3=Terry Victor|title=The Concise New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7UIjVGcSe8MC&pg=PA154|date= 2007|publisher=Psychology Press|page=154}}</ref> Within the legal profession, the term Bay Street is also used colloquially to refer to the large, full-service business law firms of Toronto.
==History== The street was originally known as '''Bear Street''' because of frequent bear sightings in the early history of Toronto.<ref>City of Toronto Archives, Bay Street index card</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Peppiatt|first1=Liam|title=Chapter 19: A Sketch of the Grange|url=http://www.landmarksoftoronto.com/a-sketch-of-the-grange|website=Robertson's Landmarks of Toronto Revisited}}</ref> It was renamed Bay Street in 1797 from the fact that it connected Lot Street (present-day [[Queen Street West]]) to a bay at the [[Toronto Harbour]]. In the 19th century the intersection of Bay and [[King Street (Toronto)|King Street]] was home to Toronto's major newspapers: the [[The Mail Building (Toronto)|Mail Building]], the [[old Toronto Star Building]], and the [[William H. Wright Building]] (old ''Globe and Mail'' headquarters) were all located near the intersection.
Until 1922, the section of Bay running north from Queen Street and ending at [[College Street (Toronto)|College Street]] was known as '''Terauley Street''' (named after the Terauley estate of [[John Simcoe Macaulay]] near Bay and Queen Streets). Several discontinuous streets existed north of College Street to [[Davenport Road]]. By-Law 9316 joined these streets together as far north as Scollard Street in 1922.<ref>City of Toronto. ''By-Law No. 9316''. "Appendix 'B{{'"}} to the Minutes of Proceedings to the Council of the Corporation for the City of Toronto for the year 1922: Volume Two. Toronto: The Carswell Co. 1922. p. 589.</ref> Finally, By-Law 9884, enacted on January 28, 1924, changed the name of Ketchum Avenue to Bay Street, extending it to Davenport Road.<ref>City of Toronto. ''By-Law No. 9884''. "Appendix 'B{{'"}} to the Minutes of Proceedings to the Council of the Corporation for the City of Toronto for the year 1924: Volume Two. Toronto: The Carswell Co. 1924.</ref> There is a short street called '''Terauley Lane''' running west of Bay from Grenville Street to Grosvenor Street.
==Points of interest== The intersection of Bay and [[King Street (Toronto)|King Street]] is often seen as the centre of Canadian banking and finance. Four of Canada's five major banks have office towers at the intersection — the [[Bank of Montreal]] at [[First Canadian Place]], [[Scotiabank]] at [[Scotia Plaza]], the [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]] (CIBC) at [[Commerce Court]], and [[Toronto-Dominion Bank]] at the [[Toronto-Dominion Centre]] — and the fifth, the [[Royal Bank of Canada|Royal Bank]] at [[Royal Bank Plaza]], is one block south. Historically, Bay and King was known as the "MINT Corner" from '''M'''ontreal, '''I'''mperial, '''N'''ova Scotia, and '''T'''oronto, <!--not Toronto-Dominion until 1955 --> but since 1961 the [[Imperial Bank of Canada|Imperial Bank]] has been part of CIBC and the Bank of Nova Scotia has rebranded itself, so this nickname is no longer widely used. The core cluster of towers has crept north with the addition of the 50-storey [[Bay Adelaide Centre]] and [[The Adelaide Hotel Toronto]].
Significant [[condominium]] development on Bay, north of the financial district, boomed during the 1990s and construction continues on large, 40-plus storey condominiums and multi-use buildings today. The area is defined by Dundas Street to the south and Bloor/Yorkville to the north and crosses through Toronto's [[Discovery District]] and [[Mink Mile]].
The area attracts many who work in the financial district and those who work in the Discovery District, nearby hospitals and schools (Ryerson University and the University of Toronto). More than 67% (or 10,380) of residents in this area are in the working ages of 25-64, significantly higher than the City of Toronto's average of 58%.<ref name="profile">[http://www.toronto.ca/demographics/cns_profiles/2006/pdf1/cpa76.pdf Gender and Age]</ref>
Notable buildings include: * [[Toronto Coach Terminal]] * [[Residences of College Park]] * [[College Park (Toronto)|777 Bay]] * [[Murano, Toronto|Murano]] * [[Ontario Government Buildings]] * [[Sutton Place Hotel]] * [[Manulife Centre]] * [[Nathan Phillips Square]] * Flagship store of [[Hudson's Bay Company]]
Another prominent intersection is the one nearest [[Yorkville, Toronto|Yorkville]] at Bay and [[Bloor Street|Bloor]], the centre of an expensive shopping district.
The intersection of Bay and Bloor is the location of the [[Toronto Transit Commission]]'s [[Bay station (Toronto)|Bay subway station]]. Bay Street is served by the [[List of Toronto Transit Commission bus routes|route 6 Bay bus]], which is one of the few downtown bus routes. The street used to be served by [[Toronto streetcar system|streetcars lines]], which were gradually phased out after the north-south [[Yonge–University–Spadina line|Yonge and University subway lines]] opened in 1954 and 1963 respectively. The remaining streetcar tracks between Dundas and College Streets are now used for short turns and diversions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://transit.toronto.on.ca/streetcar/4117.shtml |title=The Dupont and Bay Streetcars (Deceased) |author=James Bow |date=November 10, 2006 |work= |publisher=Transit Toronto |accessdate=September 22, 2012}}</ref>

{{not to be confused with|BNN Bloomberg}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = Bloomberg TV Canada | logofile = Bloomberg TV Canada Logo.png | logocaption = '''Bloomberg TV Canada logo''' | logosize = | launch = November 17, 2015 | closed date = October 5, 2017 | picture format = | network = | owner = [[Channel Zero (company)|Channel Zero]] | slogan = | country = Canada | broadcast area = National | headquarters = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | former names = | replaced names = | sister names = | web = {{url|http://bloombergtv.ca|Bloomberg TV Canada}} | sat serv 1 = | sat chan 1 = | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = | iptv chan 1 = | iptv serv 2 = | iptv chan 2 = | iptv serv 3 = | iptv chan 3 = | iptv serv 4 = | iptv chan 4 = }} '''Bloomberg TV Canada''' was a [[Television in Canada|Canadian]] [[English language]] [[Category B Services|Category B]] [[specialty channel|television channel]] owned by [[Channel Zero (company)|Channel Zero]]. It was a localized version of the U.S. financial news channel [[Bloomberg Television]]; its programming was largely identical, but also featured [[Regional variation|opt-outs]] for domestic programs covering Canadian business news.
The channel launched on November 17, 2015, replacing the American version that was readily available in Canada. The channel shut down on October 5, 2017 and Bloomberg subsequently partnered with its established Canadian competitor [[Business News Network]] (now BNN Bloomberg).
==History== On February 26, 2015, Channel Zero announced it had reached an agreement with [[Bloomberg L.P.]] to launch a localized Canadian business news channel as an offshoot of its original American Bloomberg Television channel which was currently being distributed in Canada for several years at the time. It was later announced that the channel was expected to launch on November 16, 2015 with its studios located in [[downtown Toronto]] in the city's financial district.<ref>[http://www.chch.com/bloombergchannel-zero-launch-24-7-business-news-channel/ Bloomberg/Channel Zero to launch 24-7 Business News channel] CHCH February 26, 2015</ref><ref>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/amanda-lang-to-host-evening-show-for-bloomberg-tv-canada/article26820472/</ref> [[File:Bloomberg TV Canada 2015.png|right|200px|thumb|Original logo used from 2015 to 2016]] The channel launched one day later than expected on November 17, 2015.<ref>[http://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/media-alert---bloomberg-tv-canada-launches-delivering-business-and-financial-news-to-more-than-six-million-canadian-households-551093121.html Media Alert - Bloomberg TV Canada Launches, Delivering Business and Financial News to more than Six Million Canadian Households] Canada News Wire 11-17-15</ref> At the time of launch, the American service was withheld from being distributed by Canadian television service providers at the request of its owners, although it remained a legally authorized channel for distribution in Canada by the [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC).
Programming on the service largely mirrored the American channel's schedule, with the additional programs such as ''Bloomberg North'' and ''The Daily Brief'', which were later cancelled and replaced with ''Bloomberg Markets: Canada'' in January 2017, and [[Infomercial|paid programming]].
Originally launched as an exempt discretionary service that did not require a [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission|CRTC]]-granted television licence as it did not at launch have the required 200,000 subscribers, the channel was granted a CRTC licence on August 17, 2017 after reaching that subscriber level in 2016.<ref>[http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2017/2017-288.htm Broadcasting Decision CRTC 2017-288], CRTC, 08-17-17</ref>
On the same day Channel Zero was granted its licence for Bloomberg TV Canada by the CRTC, Channel Zero announced in a statement that it would be cancelling all Canadian original productions for the channel and laying off 22 members of its staff relating to those productions, leading to speculation of how Channel Zero would maintain its required Canadian content quotas with no original Canadian productions. The statement referred to September 1, 2017 as the date the channel will be "changing the focus" of its programming, however, still maintaining that the channel will focus on business news and information, with reporting from Bloomberg studios in Canada and around the world, suggesting the channel will remain in operation.<ref>[http://www.globeinvestor.com/servlet/ArticleNews/story/GAM/20170818/RBCDBLOOMBERGTV Bloomberg TV Canada slashes its two original shows], GlobeInvestor.com, 08-18-17</ref> However, on October 5, 2017, the channel was discontinued and replaced with the American Bloomberg Television service,<ref>[https://community.shaw.ca/docs/DOC-13285 Oct 5 | Bloomberg TV Canada rebrands to Bloomberg TV], Shaw Support, 10-04-17</ref> the channel Bloomberg TV Canada replaced at its launch in 2015. The CRTC granted a request by Channel Zero to revoke the broadcasting licence for Bloomberg TV Canada on December 8, 2017.<ref>[http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2017/2017-436.htm Broadcasting Decision CRTC 2017-436], CRTC, 12-08-17</ref>
In January 2018, Bloomberg partnered with [[Bell Media]]'s [[Business News Network]] (BNN), renaming it [[BNN Bloomberg]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/telecom/media/bnn-to-become-bnn-bloomberg-in-new-deal-between-bell-media-and-bloomberg-media|title=BNN to become BNN Bloomberg in new deal between Bell Media and Bloomberg Media|date=2018-01-08|work=Financial Post|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bnn.ca/bnn-to-rebrand-as-bnn-bloomberg-through-new-bell-media-bloomberg-media-partnership-1.961761|title=BNN to rebrand as 'BNN Bloomberg' through new Bell Media-Bloomberg Media partnership|date=2018-01-08|work=BNN|access-date=2018-01-11}}</ref>
==Personalities== On October 13, 2015, [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] announced Amanda Lang was leaving for Bloomberg TV Canada. The network also hired former [[Business News Network|BNN]] journalists Pamela Ritchie as anchor of ''The Daily Brief'' and Michael Bancroft as executive producer of the channel.<ref>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/amanda-lang-to-host-evening-show-for-bloomberg-tv-canada/article26820472/</ref><ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/10/15/amanda-lang-bloomberg-canada_n_8303028.html</ref>
After Bloomberg TV Canada launched, [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] reporter/anchor [[Danielle Bochove]] joined her former colleague at Bloomberg TV Canada primarily on a part-time basis, serving as substitute anchor for ''Bloomberg North'' and, occasionally, ''The Daily Brief'', in addition to occasional reporting duties covering Canadian financial markets alongside her colleagues.<ref>https://twitter.com/daniellebochove</ref>
In February 2016,<ref>[http://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/bloomberg-tv-canada-launches-new-weekday-show-bloomberg-north-featuring-all-star-anchor-ensemble-amanda-lang-pat-kiernan-and-rudyard-griffiths-569834751.html Bloomberg TV Canada Launches New Weekday Show Bloomberg North Featuring All-Star Anchor Ensemble: Amanda Lang, Pat Kiernan and Rudyard Griffiths], Newswire, 02-23-16</ref> [[Channel Zero (company)|Channel Zero]] shuffled around its ''Bloomberg North'' anchor team, reducing [[Amanda Lang]] to Tuesdays & Wednesdays and luring away her fellow [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] and [[Business News Network|BNN]] colleague [[Rudyard Griffiths]] as anchor of the Monday program along with another former Lang colleague, [[Pat Kiernan]], who returned to Canada to join Bloomberg TV Canada and who previously worked for [[CNNfn]] anchoring ''The Money Gang'' with Lang, [[Christine Romans]] and [[Ali Velshi]] between 2000-2004, anchoring on Thursdays. Griffiths, Lang and Kiernan rotate on Fridays anchoring an "encore"-type show recapping the week's business news stories and interviews.<ref>https://twitter.com/rudyardg</ref><ref>https://twitter.com/patkiernan</ref>
In March 2016, [[Global Television Network|Global National]] business and consumer affairs reporter [[Jamie Sturgeon]] left to join Bloomberg TV Canada as a general assignment reporter covering Canadian financial markets.<ref>https://twitter.com/jasturgeon</ref> Shortly thereafter, former [[National Post]] newspaper reporter [[Eric Lam]] for their [[Financial Post]] business and markets section joined Bloomberg TV Canada as another general assignment reporter covering Canadian financial markets.<ref>https://twitter.com/ericlamTO</ref>
As of May 2016, former [[TechTV]] ''Call For Help'' co-host and [[Business News Network|BNN]] ''App Central'' co-host [[Amber MacArthur]] has been seen occasionally filling in as a substitute co-anchor of ''Bloomberg North'' alongside [[WIND Mobile]] co-founder [[Anthony Lacavera]], including the program on August 16, 2016.<ref>https://twitter.com/ambermac</ref><ref>https://twitter.com/TonyLacavera</ref>
In January 2017, former [[Reuters TV]] journalist, Lily Jamali joined Bloomberg TV Canada to host a new daily Bloomberg Markets: Canada, a 30-minute program recapping the day's market news.<ref>[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/lily-jamali-joins-bloomberg-tv-133000780.html Lily Jamali Joins Bloomberg TV Canada], Yahoo Finance, 01-19-17</ref>

revision.text:
'''Bob Dhillon''' is the founder, president and CEO of [[Mainstreet Equities Corp|Mainstreet Equity Corp (MEQ)]] which owns and manages billions of dollars worth of Canadian real estate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mainst.biz|title=Mainstreet Equity Corp. (MEQ)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Bob Dhillon currently sits on the Canadian Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) Board, the biggest [[Crown corporations of Canada|Canadian Crown Corporation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/corp/about/cogo/cogo_002.cfm|title=Canadian Mortgage & Housing Corporation Board|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Dhillon is the Honorary Consul General for [[Belize]] in Canada<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.belizeconsulatealberta.com/content/|title=Belize Honorary Consul General|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and owns a private 3,000-acre island in Belize that he is developing into a world-class tourist resort. Dhillon has further interest in the country of Belize as he is the published author of the book 'Business and Retirement Guide to Belize' currently in its second edition.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Business and Retirement Guide to Belize|last=Bob Dhillon|first=Fred Langan|publisher=Dundurn|year=2018|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Dhillon also currently sits on the Entrepreneur Advisory Council for the [[Ivey Business School|Richard Ivey School of Business]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ivey.uwo.ca/entrepreneurship/about/advisory-council/|title=Advisory Council {{!}} Richard Ivey School of Business|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In March 2018, Dhillon partnered with the [[University of Lethbridge]] to become the ''[[eponym]]ous'' [[Organizational founder|founder]] of the [[Dhillon School of Business]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/news/fp-street/bob-dhillon-gives-back-with-10-million-donation-to-the-university-of-lethbridge|title=Bob Dhillon 'gives back' with $10 million donation to the University of Lethbridge|last=Critchley|first=Barry|date=March 14, 2018|work=Financial Post|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> which will provide innovative approaches to education with an emphasis on futuristic learning. The Dhillon School of Business largest educational fields aimed at teaching [[blockchain]], [[cryptocurrency]], [[artificial intelligence]] and other growth industries. Dhillon completed his M.B.A. degree from the Richard Ivey School of Business at the University of Western Ontario in 1998<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/economy/business/dhillon-dollar-strategy/|title=Dhillon Dollar Strategy|last=Newman|first=Peter C.|date=July 2, 2009|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and later received an [[Honorary degree|Honorary Doctorate degree]] from [[Lakehead University]] in 2017<ref name=":3" /> [[File:Bob Dhillon Founder Mainstreet Equity.jpg|alt=Bob Dhillon CEO, Founder & President of Mainstreet Equity|none|thumb|Bob Dhillon is the founder, chief executive officer, and president of Mainstreet Equity. He is a leading Canadian real estate owner and asset manager with experience in acquiring and repositioning properties.]]
== Early Life & Education ==
Dhillon's family comes from [[Tallewal]] in the district of [[Barnala]] [[Punjab, India|Punjab]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/canadas-top-businessman-bob-singh-dhillon-donates-10-mn-to-university-of-lethbridge/articleshow/63315128.cms|title=Canada's top businessman Bob Singh Dhillon donates $10 mn to University of Lethbridge|last=|first=|date=|work=The Economic Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> His father, a trader, left for [[Hong Kong]] for business reasons and set-up the North China Shipping Company. Dhillon was born in [[Japan]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.darpanmagazine.com/people/businessleaders/bob-dhillon-chapters-of-the-first-sikh-billionaire/|title=Bob Dhillon – Chapters of the First Sikh Billionaire|last=Lehail|first=Jessie|date=January 31, 2014|work=Darpan Magazine|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> but as a small child he was sent back to [[India]] for his schooling, where he was educated at Bishop Cotton School in [[Shimla]]. At the age of 12, Dhillon migrated to Canada where he continued his education in Calgary, Alberta. After graduating from University, he went to complete his master's degree ([[MBA]]) at [[Richard Ivey School of Business]] in [[London, Ontario]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ivey.uwo.ca/entrepreneurship/about/advisory-council/bob-dhillon/|title=Bob Dhillon, EMBA '98|last=|first=|date=1998|website=University Of Western Ontario {{!}} Ivy School Of Business|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Dhillon began his career in real estate at the age of 19 finding under-valued property and repositioning it,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-magazine/calgarys-bob-dhillon-reinvents-the-apartment-building-business/article559701/|title=Calgary's Bob Dhillon reinvents the apartment-building business|last=Sthankiya|first=Nayan|date=October 27, 2011|work=The Globe & Mail|access-date=March 26, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> starting by buying a pair of houses in Calgary; renovating and selling them for a profit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mainst.biz/investors/management-team|title=Mainstreet Equity (MEQ) Management Team|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Mainstreet Equity Corporation== [[File:Mainstreet Tower in Edmonton.jpg|alt=Mainstreet Tower in Edmonton, Alberta|thumb|Mainstreet Tower in Edmonton, Alberta]] Dhillon founded [https://mainst.biz Mainstreet Equity Corp] which was listed as a [[Lists of companies listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange|Canadian publicly traded company on the Toronto Stock Exchange]] listed on the TSX as MEQ. Bob Dhillon is the corporation's largest shareholder, founder, [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] & president. Mainstreet Equity Corp. is based out of [[Calgary|Calgary, Alberta]] and engages in the acquisition, redevelopment, repositioning and management of mid-market Canadian apartment complexes. Mainstreet Equity currently has properties in Alberta (Calgary, Edmonton, Lethbridge, Fort Saskatchewan & Cochrane), British Columbia (Surrey, Abbotsford & New Westminster) and Saskatchewan (Saskatoon & Regina)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.tmxmoney.com/company.php?qm_symbol=MEQ|title=TMX Money (TSX)|last=|first=|date=April 4, 2018|website=TMX Money|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> with current asset value exceeding $1.8 billion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/mainstreet-equity-corp-releases-q1-2018-results-673897953.html|title=[MEQ] Mainstreet Equity Q1 2018 Results|last=|first=|date=Feb 13, 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Since its conception in 2000 Mainstreet has grown its portfolio from 272 units with an approximate market value $17 million to 11,566 units and approximately $1.8 billion market value in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mainst.biz/investors/company-overview|title=Mainstreet Equity Company Overview|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Through the years, Dhillon and Mainstreet Equity have become a value creator through purchasing under-performing [[real estate]], and renovating the properties to meet a higher standard.
Under Dhillon, Mainstreet has achieved a 1,270% return on investment from September 2003 to September 2014, making it Canada's highest performing real estate company. The company's assets consist of over 12,000 apartment units in [[Western Canada]].
Mainstreet Equity Corporation differs from other real estate companies as it is a corporation and not a [[Real estate investment trust|REIT]], operating as a add-value consolidator of mid-market multi-family apartment buildings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.canadianbusiness.com/investing/mainstreet-equity/|title=Stock pick: Mainstreet Equity Corp (MEQ) buys fixer-upper rentals for double-digit growth|last=Borzykowski|first=Bryan|date=May 26, 2014|work=Canadian Business|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Mainstreet Equity has positioned itself in the Canadian market place to specialize in the acquisition of mid-market multi-family properties. The term "[[Mid market price|Mid-market]]" is used to define a property by size, location, condition, and management. Generally, in the Canadian marketplace mid-market properties have less than 100 units, making them less attractive to large institutional investors. Buildings that are considered to be 'mid-market' are often mismanaged and left in relatively poor condition, often requiring renovations or upgrades to bring them to the market standard. Mainstreet Equity is able to attract renters and tenants to their properties through their innovative approach, providing renovated apartment rentals that are often below the standard market price and branded as boutique apartments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mainst.biz/investors/company-overview|title=Mainstreet Equity (MEQ) Company Overview|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[File:Bob Dhillon Calgary, Alberta..jpg|alt=Bob Dhillon Calgary|none|thumb|Bob Dhillon in front of Mainstreet property in Calgary, Alberta.]]
[[File:Avenue Tower Mainstreet Equity.jpg|alt= Mainstreet Equity Avenue Tower|none|thumb|Avenue Tower a Mainstreet Equity property in Downtown Calgary on 17th Ave SW]]
== Dhillon School of Business == [[File:Dhillon School Of Business Logo.jpg|alt=Dhillon School Of Business Logo|none|thumb|Dhillon School Of Business Logo]]
In March 2018, Dhillon with the University of Lethbridge established the Dhillon School of Business, which aims to provide innovative approaches to education with an emphasis on futuristic learning.
Dhillon's generous gift of $10 million to the University of Lethbridge came with the goal of transforming the University of Lethbridge's faculty of management into one of the leading fintech schools in the country focusing on progressive and innovative fields like; blockchain, cryptocurrencies, and artificial intelligence.
The Dhillon School of Business is looking to add to the university's curriculum with the study of disruptive financial technologies such as [[artificial intelligence]], [[blockchain]], and cryptocurrencies like [[Bitcoin]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/education/the-university-of-lethbridges-10-million-fintech-transformation/|title=The University of Lethbridge's $10-million fintech transformation|last=Davis|first=Anthony A.|date=March 26, 2018|work=Maclean's Magazine|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Belize == Dhillon is the [[Consul (representative)|Honorary Consul General]] for Belize in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.embassypages.com/missions/embassy8971/|title=Embassy Pages|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He currently owns a 3,000-acre private island in Belize located near Belize's largest island, [[Ambergris Caye]], and the popular Caribbean destination of [[San Pedro Town]].
Dhillon is currently developing the island into a world-class tourist resort. Outside of active investment in Belize, Dhillon has further interest in Belize as he is the published author of the book 'Business and Retirement Guide to Belize' currently in its second edition.<ref name=":0" />
=== Belize Philanthropy === Bob Dhillon's influence in Belize has been seen through infrastructure projects and philanthropy including donations towards San Pedro Town and raising money for underprivileged children.
* Donating $500,000 to the town of [[San Pedro Town|San Pedro, Belize]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sanpedrosun.com/old/08-282.html|title=Costa del Sol donates BZ$500K to San Pedro, Belize News, San Pedro Sun|website=www.sanpedrosun.com|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> * Raising $60,000 for underprivileged children in San Pedro<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ambergristoday.com/news/2010/10/05/canadian-multi-millionaire-donates-underprivileged-children|title=Canadian Multi-Millionaire donates to Underprivileged Children|date=2010-10-05|work=Ambergris Today|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en}}</ref>
== Notable Achievements ==
* Recipient of [[Honorary degree|Honorary Doctorate degree]] from [[Lakehead University]] 2017<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.lakeheadu.ca/about/news-and-events/news/archive/2017/node/42269|title=Lakehead University announces its 2017 Convocation Ceremonies’ Honorary Doctorates and Fellows {{!}} Lakehead University|website=Lakehead University|language=en|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref>
* Recipient of the Ernst & Young 2015 Entrepreneur of the Year for the Prairies Real Estate & Construction category <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ey.com/ca/en/newsroom/news-releases/2015-ey-announces-2015-prairies-entrepreneur-of-the-year-program-finalists|title=EY announces 2015 Prairies Entrepreneur Of The Year™ program finalists|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * Recognized as one of the 2015 [[Royal Bank of Canada|RBC]] Top 25 Canadian Immigrant Award winners<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://canadianimmigrant.ca/canadas-top-25-immigrants/canadas-top-25-immigrants-2015/|title=Canadas Top 25 Immigrants 2015|work=Canadian Immigrant|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-US}}</ref> * Recipient of The [[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal|Queen's Diamond Jubilee Medal]] * Recognition by Alberta Venture magazine as one of Alberta's 50 Most Influential People * Recognized as one of the 25 Most Influential Indians in North America<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://immigrantservicescalgary.ca/ida/award-recipients/2016/bob-dhillon|title=Bob Dhillon {{!}} Immigrant Services revision.text:
The [[computer graphics]] supervisor, or '''CG Supervisor''', is a person involved in the production of [[computer generated imagery]], be it [[animation]] or [[visual effects]]. Due to the variety of productions and duties required, most CG supervisors are specialized in one area such as [[art]], [[computer programming|programming]], or management. On large productions, there might be several CG Supervisors, each concentrating on a specific area.
Typical duties of the CG supervisor include:
*Designing and implementing the technical, artistic pipeline and [[workflow]] of a production. *Designing and possibly implementing tools used in production. *Assisting the [[movie producer|producer]] by reviewing [[budget]]s and schedules. *Training the [[film crew|crew]] and making sure the tools required for the project are up to the task. *Designing and supervising the creation of CG imagery. *Leading the [[technical director]]s (TDs) in solving problems the production faces on a day-to-day basis. *Assisting and supervising the [[artist]]s in achieving the artistic goals of the production.
Due to the variety of tasks and the obligations of [[problem solving]] as the "go-to person", the CG supervisor is usually able to handle any individual part of the production in addition to managing.
[[Category:Computer graphics professionals]] [[Category:Management occupations]]

'''Cookeen''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] brand of block [[Shortening|vegetable fat]], marketed for use in making [[pastry]], and other baked goods. It is claimed to be usable straight from the [[refrigerator]].
It is sold by [[Princes (company)|Princes Limited]], a British food producer owned by [[Mitsubishi]]. The brand is owned by '''Edible Oils Limited''', a joint venture between [[Archer Daniels Midland]] (ADM), an American food processing corporation, and Princes. The product is produced at a factory in [[Erith]], England.
In October 2006, Cookeen and the other hard vegetable fats manufactured by Edible Oils Limited were reformulated to remove hydrogenated vegetable oils, which contain [[trans fat]], due to health concerns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Home baking brands remove hydrogenated vegetable oil|url=http://www.princesgroup.com/news/home-baking-brands-remove-hydrogenated-vegetable-oil/|accessdate=19 November 2013|date=1 December 2006}}</ref>
==Popular Culture==
[[Matt Lucas]] used the line "Give 'em a little lift with cookeen." in a parody song for his character [[George Dawes]] on the [[British comedy]] [[panel show]] ''[[Shooting Stars (TV series)|Shooting Stars]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.princes.co.uk/ Princes Limited] *[http://www.princesgroup.com/brands/cookeen/ Cookeen website from Princes Limited]

{{Infobox family | name = De Dietrich | crest = | crestcaption = | image = Jan de Dietrich--De Dietrich--.jpg | imagecaption = ''Jean de Dietrich'' | region = France | early_forms = | origin = Europe | members = Philippe-Frédéric de Dietrich | connectedmembers = | otherfamilies = | distinctions = | traditions = | heirlooms = | estate = | meaning = | website = | footnotes = }}
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:De Dietrich family crest.jpg|thumb|''Family crest'']] -->{{Single source|date=October 2018}}
The history of the '''de Dietrich''' family has been linked to that of France and of Europe for over three centuries. To this day, the company that bears the family name continues to play a major role in the economic life of [[Alsace]]. De Dietrich is a holding company based in France which traces its history back to 1684. The incumbent chairman of the supervisory board Marc-Antoine de Dietrich represents the 11th consecutive generation at the helm of the company. De Dietrich has been active in the automobile, railway and industrial equipment industry amongst others.
==History==
[[File:Bischheim Château d'Angleterre côté jardin (façade sud).jpg|thumb|South side of ''Château d'Angleterre'' seen through the gardens in 2013]] ''1684 :'' Johann von Dietrich acquires the Jaegerthal forge.
''1719 :'' The family is made Baron by the [[Holy Roman Empire]].
''1749-1751 :'' Baron Jean de Dietrich has the castle and gardens of [[Château de la Cour d'Angleterre]] built in [[Bischheim (Bas-Rhin)|Bischheim]] near [[Strasbourg]]
''1761 :'' Baron Jean de Dietrich is made Count du [[Ban de la Roche]] by [[Louis XV]]. He becomes the largest land owner in Alsace and expands the family's industrial empire by building or acquiring forges and furnaces. [[File:Pils - Rouget de Lisle chantant la Marseillaise.jpg|right|thumb|200x700px|''Rouget de Lisle singing the "Marseillaise"'' - Pils]]
''1778 :'' Louis XVI grants Jean de Dietrich the use of a hunting horn trademark to deter counterfeiters. This logo still serves as a symbol of quality today.
''1792 :'' [[Philippe Friedrich Dietrich|Philippe-Frédéric de Dietrich]] (Jean's son), first [[List of mayors of Strasbourg|mayor of Strasbourg]] in republican France, orders captain [[Rouget de Lisle]] to compose a military hymn for the [[Army of the Rhine]]. First sung in Philippe-Frederic's parlor on [[Place Broglie]], "[[La Marseillaise]]" became France's national anthem.
''1804 :'' After the havoc left by the French Revolution, [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] helps De Dietrich rebuild.
''1848 :'' De Dietrich embraces the industrial era by progressively reducing the production of cast irons in favor of mechanical and railroad equipment.
''1870 :'' Despite the [[Franco-Prussian War|annexation by Germany]] of [[Alsace-Lorraine]], the Dietrich family decides to remain close to the factories and employees and stays in Alsace. This choice calls for a diversification of De Dietrich's activities in order to adapt to German market demands and having been effectively shun out of the French railroad market. The company then turns towards consumer durables: stoves, cookers, wooden furniture, enameled cast iron bathtubs – and urban or industrial equipment – tramways, distillation equipment, industry specific wagons.
''1896 :'' De Dietrich enters automobile manufacturing. Eugene, [[Baron de Turckheim]], buys manufacturing rights to [[Amédée-Ernest-Marie Bollée|Amédée Bollée, ''fils'']]' design.<ref>Wise, David Burgess. "De Dietrich: France's Veteran Car Manufacturer", in Northey, Tom, ed. ''World of Automobiles'' (London: Orbis, 1974), Volume 5, p.507.</ref> During its automotive development it hired amongst others the services of famous car builder [[Ettore Bugatti]] to design of the cars and [[Émile Mathis]] to handle commercialization.
[[File:De Dietrich Licence Bugatti Touring car.jpg|thumb|left|200x700px|''Bugatti's first car'']] [[File:Logo Lorraine-Dietrich.jpg|thumb|right|''Logo for the Lorraine-Dietrich cars'']]
''1905 :'' De Dietrich decides to pull out of automobile manufacturing to focus on mechanical construction, railroad equipment, process systems, central heating equipment and appliances.
''1992 :'' De Dietrich assumes control of Cogifer, market leader fixed railroad installations and forgives control of the appliances business to Thomson, control later on assumed by [[Fagor|Fagor-Brandt]]until this day.
''1995 :'' De Dietrich sells its interest in rolling stock railroad equipment manufacturing "[[De Dietrich Ferroviaire]]" (DDF's factory is in [[Reichshoffen]]". A majority stake in DDF was acquired by [[Alstom]] and the company is now known as Alstom-DDF.
''2000 :'' After the successive acquisitions of Rosenmund-Guedu and QVF, De Dietrich renames its chemical equipment division "De Dietrich Process Systems". De Dietrich is the object a Public Tender Offer by the la Société Industrielle du Hanau (SIH), controlled by [[ABN AMRO]] Capital Investissement France and the De Dietrich family.
''2001 :'' In July 2001, after 50 years of quotation, De Dietrich is pulled out the market. [[File:Reichshoffen-Château De Dietrich (4).jpg|right|thumb|200x800px|''Château De Dietrich - De Dietrich Headquarters - Reichshoffen'']] ''2002 :'' In September 2002, De Dietrich sells the control of Cogifer and Cogifer TF, to [[Vossloh]] a German Industrial group specialized in railroad equipment. In December 2002, the "Société Industrielles du Hanau" takes over De Dietrich & Cie and assumes the name "De Dietrich".
''2004 :'' In July 2004, De Dietrich divests from "De Dietrich Thermique", market leader in water heating equipment to Remeha. The new entity formed [[De Dietrich Remeha]], becomes one of Europe's largest heating industry player, particularly in the fields of condensing boilers and renewable energies.
In December 2004, the family regained 100% control of the holding company. This operation represents one of Europe's largest family re-investments in recent years. De Dietrich today focuses on [http://www.dedietrich.com/ De Dietrich Process Systems](DDPS). DDPS is a leading worldwide provider of API process and other process equipment to the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries. with an industrial presence in Asia, Europe and USA. The latest factories added to the Group are located in [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] and [[Wuxi]].
==Genealogy==
[[Demange Dietrich]] (1549-), Strasbourg bourgeois x Anne Heller │ └── Jean Dietrich (17 février 1579-1642), councilman and merchant in Strasbourg x Agnès Meyer │ └── [[Dominique Dietrich]] (1620-1694), "amnestre" of Strasbourg (Mayor) x Ursule Wencker (1627-1662) │ └── [[Jean-Nicolas Dietrich]] (1688-1726), merchant, banker x Marie-Barbe Kniebs (1665-1747) │ └── [[Jean de Dietrich (1719-1795)|Jean de Dietrich]] (1719-1795), Count of the "Ban de la Roche" x Amélie Hermanny (1729-1766) │ ├── [[Jean de Dietrich (1746-1805)|Jean de Dietrich]] (1746-1805) │ x Louise-Sophie de Glaubitz (1751-1806) │ └── [[Philippe-Frédéric de Dietrich]] (1748- beheaded 1793), mayor of Strasbourg x Sybille-Louise Ochs (1755-1806) │ └── [[Jean-Albert de Dietrich]] (1773-1806), head of Bas-Rhin region x Amélie de Berckheim (1776-1855) │ ├── Amélie de Dietrich (1799-1854) │ x Guillaume de Turckheim (1785-1831), Major │ ├── Baron [[Albert de Dietrich (1802-1888)|Albert de Dietrich]] (1802-1888), │ x 1828 Octavie von Stein (1801-1839) │ │ │ ├── Baron [[Albert de Dietrich (1831-)|Albert de Dietrich]] (1831-) │ │ x Sophie von und zu der Tann-Rathsamhausen (1832-1890) │ │ │ x 1840 Adélaïde von Stein │ │ │ └── [[Eugène-Dominique de Dietrich]] (1844-1918), deputy for Alsace at the Reichstag │ x Cécile Vaucher │ │ │ └── [[Dominique de Dietrich]] (1892-1963), │ x Inès-Agnès de Pourtalès │ │ │ └── [[Gilbert de Dietrich]] (1928-2006), CEO of De Dietrich from 1968 to 1996 │ x Suzanne Syz (29 août 1925 - 15 février 1975) │ │ │ └── Baron Marc-Antoine de Dietrich, Incumbent Chairman of De Dietrich Supervisory board │ x Catherine Probst │ │ └── [[Jean-Sigismond de Dietrich]] (1803-1868), x Virginie Mathis (1810-1867) │ └── Amélie de Dietrich (1841-1874) x Baron Édouard de Turkheim
==See also==

revision.text:
'''Sir John Derek Alun-Jones ''' (6 June 1933 – 19 January 2008) was a British businessman and chairman of [[Ferranti]] at the time of its merger with US company [[International Signal and Control]] (ISC).
He was educated at [[Lancing College]] and [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford]], where he read Law. He began his career with [[Philips Industrial]] in 1957, and became managing director of [[Expandite]] in 1966. He moved to [[Burmah Oil]] in 1971, and became a director of Burmah Oil Trading before moving to Ferranti in 1975.
Alun-Jones was appointed chairman of Ferranti in 1982 and oversaw the £420 million merger with the [[Pennsylvania]] based company International Signal & Control in 1987. However, it soon became apparent that a subsidiary of ISC had been involved in a huge fraud which had inflated the value of ISC at the time of the merger. Ferranti went into receivership in 1993.
He remained a director of several companies after leaving Ferranti and was chairman of the governors of Lancing College from 1986 to 1999. He was knighted in 1987.
==References== {{reflist}} *http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1577871/Sir-Derek-Alun-Jones.html *http://thepeerage.com/p22475.htm#i224749

{{lowercase title}} {{Infobox company | name = eMarketer, Inc. | logo=EMarketer logo.jpeg | type=[[Publicly held|Public]] | industry= [[Market research]] | num_employees = 201-500 {{cite web|author=|url=http://us.linkedin.com/company/emarketer-inc |title=eMarketer, Inc. LinkedIn Company Profile |publisher=[[LinkedIn]]|date= |accessdate=2018-08-22}} | homepage = [http://www.emarketer.com eMarketer] | location_city = [[Eleven Times Square]]
[[New York, NY]] | foundation= 1996 | owner= [[Axel Springer]] }} '''eMarketer''' is a 93%-owned subsidiary [[market research]] company that provides insights and trends related to [[digital marketing]], [[mass media|media]] and commerce.{{cite web|author=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/people.asp?privcapId=736862 |title=eMarketer Inc.|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=2012-09-20 |accessdate=2013-04-03}}{{cite web|author=Cain Claire|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/19/google-is-set-to-topple-facebook-as-leader-in-display-ads/|title=Google to Topple Facebook as Leader in Display Ads, eMarketer Says|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=2012-09-19 |accessdate=2012-12-21}}{{cite web|author=Robert Hof |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/roberthof/2012/01/19/online-ad-revenues-to-pass-print-in-2012/ |title=Online Ad Revenues to Pass Print in 2012 |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=2012-04-18 |accessdate=2012-12-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.library.hbs.edu/go/emarketer.html |title=Baker Library - eMarketer Database|publisher=Harvard Business School Bloomberg Center|date= |accessdate=2012-12-15}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=736862 |title=eMarketer Inc.: Private Company Information - Businessweek |publisher=[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]] |date= |accessdate=2012-12-15}} eMarketer, founded in 1996, is located in New York, NY. The company was acquired by [[Axel Springer SE|Axel Springer]] in June 2016 for $242 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emarketer-m-a-axel-sprngr-idUSKCN0YW0RE|title=Axel Springer buys U.S. eMarketer for $242 million |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=2016-06-10}} ==Products and services== === Corporate subscription === Subscribers have access to eMarketer's data via a Web-based client portal. Within the database, analysts, forecasters, and researchers publish industry reports, forecasts, comparative estimates, charts, articles, interviews, [[case studies]], [[web conferencing]] and videos. The company curates, compares, and contextualizes information from global sources to provide macro-level understanding of digital trends related to [[advertising]], marketing, media and commerce.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/emarketer |title=eMarketer CrunchBase Profile |publisher= [[Crunchbase]] |date= |accessdate=2012-12-15}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://venturebeatprofiles.com/company/profile/emarketer-inc |title=eMarketer VentureBeat profile|publisher=[[VentureBeat]] |date= |accessdate=2012-12-15}}{{cite web|author=Lori Luechtefeld|url=http://ad-tech.blogs.imediaconnection.com/2011/04/12/emarketer-ceo-geoff-ramsey-receives-industry-achievement-award/|title=eMarketer CEO Geoff Ramsey Receives Industry Achievement Award -ad:tech|publisher=ad:tech|date=2011-04-12|accessdate=2012-12-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110417021139/http://ad-tech.blogs.imediaconnection.com/2011/04/12/emarketer-ceo-geoff-ramsey-receives-industry-achievement-award/|archivedate=2011-04-17|df=}}{{cite web|author= Yahoo!| url=http://biz.yahoo.com/ic/126/126575.html|title=eMarketer, Inc. Company Profile|publisher= Yahoo! |accessdate=2012-12-20}} === eMarketer Daily Newsletter === The "eDaily" is a free email newsletter with a circulation of 120,000+.{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.emarketer.com/Newsletter|title=eMarketer Newsletter page|publisher=eMarketer|date=|accessdate=2012-03-04}} The newsletter covers portions of eMarketer's latest analysis. Topics include trends in mobile, social and online advertising.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.linkedin.com/company/emarketer-inc/products?trk=biz_products_emarketer-inc|title=eMarketer Products & Services LinkedIn page|publisher=eMarketer|date=|accessdate=2012-03-04}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.emarketer.com}} [[Category:Market researchers]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]]

A '''Euronorm''' is an international [[technical standard]] that has been recognized as applicable by the [[European Union]]. They may be identical to international standards of the [[ISO]] or [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]], or have editorial or technical content changes for applicability in the European Union, with changes annexed to the international standard, or may be originated by a European standards organization. Organizations recognized by EU regulations to establish standards are [[European Committee for Standardization|CEN]], [[European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization|CENELEC]] and [[ETSI]]. A Euronorm becomes the equivalent of a national standard in all member countries, and replaces any prior conflicting national standard.<ref>https://www.cencenelec.eu/standards/DefEN/Pages/default.aspx ''What is a Euronorm?'', retrieved July 5, 2017</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{tech-stub}} [[Category:International standards]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox |name = |bodystyle = |title = Harold M. "Hal" Brierley |titlestyle = title |image = |imagestyle = framed |caption = photograph by Billy Surface |captionstyle = |headerstyle = |labelstyle = ; |datastyle = width:65% |header1 = |label1 = Born: |data1 = 1943 |header2 = |label2 = Residence: |data2 = Dallas, Texas |header3 = |label3 = Occupation: |data3 = Executive Chairman / Founder of Brierley+Partners |header4 = |label4 = Known for: |data4 = Pioneering AAvantage| CRM marketing |header5 = |label5 = Spouse: |data5 = Diane Walden Brierley |belowstyle = background:#ddf; |below = }} '''Harold Brierley''' is an [[United States|American]] business and marketing executive focused on [[loyalty programs]].
== Background == Born in 1943{{cn|date=October 2013}}, Brierley earned a B.S. in [[chemical engineering]] from the [[University of Maryland]] and an [[MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]] with a [[Baker Scholar]] distinction.<ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=523858&privcapId=468237&previousCapId=28717149&previousTitle=Dell%20Singapore%20Pte.%20Ltd. Executive Profile: Harold M. Brierley]. ''Bloomberg Businessweek''. Retrieved 27 November 2014.</ref><ref name="fullcircle">[https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=2672 "Professorship Brings Brierley's HBS Connection Full Circle"] Alumni Story Details. Harvard Business School (01 April 2002). Retrieved 27 November 2014.</ref> After graduating, Brierley worked as a research assistant for Harvard professor Charles M. Williams<ref name=fullcircle /> and co-founded Epsilon Data Management with former Harvard classmates in 1968.<ref>Smillie, Dirk. "Chapter 4: Bible Bling." ''Falwell Inc.: Inside a Religious, Political, Educational, and Business Empire''. New York: St. Martin's, 2008. 86-89. Print.</ref>
== Business career == In 1980, a former classmate from Harvard hired Brierley to design [[American Airlines]]' traveler rewards program.<ref>[http://www.insideflyer.com/articles/article.php?key=2926 "The Big 2-5: Celebrating 25 Years of Frequent Flyer Programs"]. ''InsideFlyer'' (May 2006)]. Retrieved 27 November 2014.</ref><ref> Petersen, Randy, and Tim Winship. "Chapter 1: Mileage Programs Take Off." ''Mileage Pro: The Insider's Guide to Frequent Flyer Programs''. Downers Grove, IL: OAG Worldwide, 2005.</ref> Brierley later became the vice president of sales and marketing for [[Pan American World Airways]] in 1982, where he developed the WorldPass loyalty program.<ref name="fullcircle" /> After a year at Pan Am, Brierley left to become the senior vice president of marketing for [[Continental Airlines]].{{CN|date=October 2013}}
== Entrepreneurial career == In 1985, Brierley opened Brierley+Partners (B+P), a loyalty program consultancy; and launched e-Rewards, Inc., a firm that collects consumer data for engineering loyalty programs, in 1999.<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/print-edition/2012/08/31/tech-titans-e-rewards-inc.html "Tech Titans: e-Rewards Inc."]. ''Dallas Business Journal'' (31 August 2012). Retrieved 27 November 2014.</ref> In 2006, Brierley created e-Miles, Inc under the B+P umbrella.<ref name="stealbook"> Cone, Steve. "Chapter 11: Loyalty Reimagined." ''Steal These Ideas!: Marketing Secrets That Will Make You a Star''. 2nd ed. New York: Bloomberg, 2012 </ref><ref name=fivequestions>Hunter, Glenn (20 January 2010).[http://www.dmagazine.com/Home/D_CEO/2010/January_February/5_Questions_for_Hal_Brierley.aspx "5 Questions for Hal Brierley."]. D CEO. ''Dallas Magazine''. Retrieved 27 November 2014.</ref>
Brierley teaches a course on the founding of Epsilon Data Management{{fact|date=October 2013}} at Harvard Business School.<ref>Hal Brierley (20 March 2012). [http://adage.com/article/guest-columnists/drowning-data-ad-business-faces-a-talent-crisis/233390/. "Drowning in Data, Our Business Faces a Serious Talent Crisis"]. Blogs & Columnists. ''Advertising Age''. Retrieved 27 November 2014.</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Brierley, Harold}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:University System of Maryland alumni]]
