revision.text:
Started in Canada in 1985, '''Responsible Care<sup>®</sup>''' is a global, voluntary initiative developed autonomously by the [[chemical industry]] for the chemical industry. It runs in 67 countries whose combined chemical industries account for nearly 90% of global chemical production. 96 of the 100 largest chemical producers in the world have adopted Responsible Care.
It stands for the chemical industry's desire to improve health, safety, and environmental performance.
The signatory chemical companies agree to commit themselves to improve their performances in the fields of [[environmental protection]], occupational safety and health protection, plant safety, product stewardship and [[logistics]], as well as to continuously improve dialog with their neighbors and the public, independent from legal requirements.
As part of Responsible Care initiative, the [[International Council of Chemical Associations]] introduced the Global Product Strategy in 2006.
Critical analyses of Responsible Care have been done by Andrew King and Michael Lenox,<ref>{{cite web|last=King A. & Lenox M.|title=Industry self-regulation without sanctions: the chemical industry's Responsible Care program|url=http://www.stern.nyu.edu/bes/papers/selfreg.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031106043307/http://www.stern.nyu.edu/bes/papers/selfreg.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2003-11-06|accessdate=2007-02-16}}</ref> Michael Givel,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Givel|first=Michael|year=2007|title=Motivation of Chemical Industry Social Responsibility Through Responsible Care|journal=Health Policy|volume=81|issue=1|pages=85–92|doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2006.05.015|pmid=16797774}}</ref> and Moffet, Bregha and Middelkoop<ref>{{cite web|url=https://carleton.ca/sppa/ccms/wp-content/ccms-files/ch6.pdf|title=Responsible Care: A Case Study of a Voluntary Environmental Initiative|accessdate=2010-11-12|author=Moffet|last= |first=John |author2=François Bregha |author3=Mary Jane Middelkoop|date=September 2007|publisher=Carleton University, School of Public Policy and Administration|pages= |doi= }}</ref>
==History== Responsible Care was launched by the [[Chemistry Industry Association of Canada]] (formerly the Canadian Chemical Producers' Association - CCPA) in 1985.<ref>[http://www.canadianchemistry.ca/ResponsibleCareHome.aspx Chemistry Industry Association of Canada]</ref> The scheme evolved, and, in 2006, The Responsible Care Global Charter was launched at the [[UN]]-led International Conference on Chemicals Management in [[Dubai]].<ref>[http://www.icca-chem.org/Global/Initiatives/RC_GlobalCharter2006%5b1%5d.pdf?epslanguage=en Responsible Care Global Charter]</ref>
==Controversy== Poisoning of river [[Elbe]] by the company [[Draslovka Kolin]] a.s., a Responsible Care certified company <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icis.com/Articles/2006/06/12/1069540/czech-draslovka-fined-over-cyanide-leak.html|title=Czech Draslovka fined over cyanide leak-12/06/2006-ICIS News|publisher=Icis.com|date=2006-06-12|accessdate=2013-06-23}}</ref> or hiding of 20 mt{{clarify|date=June 2013}} leakage of [[naphthalene]] by the company Deza,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/regiony/35188-valasskomeziricska-chemicka-deza-tajila-unik-naftalenu/|title=Valašskomeziříčská chemička Deza tajila únik naftalenu — Regiony — ČT24 — Česká televize|publisher=Ceskatelevize.cz|date=2008-11-08|accessdate=2013-06-23}}</ref> also a Responsible Care company, questions whether the Responsible Care brings any real improvement or is just a [[marketing tool]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.icca-chem.org/responsible-care/ Responsible Care web site] *[https://www.icca-chem.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Global-Product-Strategy-Sound-Chemicals-Management-as-Global-Responsibility.pdf The Global Product Strategy pdf]
[[Category:Chemical industry]]

{{Infobox company | name = SEAF | logo = SEAF logo.png | industry = [[Impact Investing]] | foundation = Washington DC, United States ({{Start date|1989 }}) | founder = {{ubl|[[Hubertus van der Vaart]]|Tom Gibson}} | location_city = [[Washington DC]] | location_country = United States | locations = 20+ offices (2017) | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = [[Hubertus van der Vaart]]
(Executive Chairman) | aum = {{increase}} $600+ million (2017) | num_employees = 145 (2017) | homepage = {{URL|seaf.com}} | footnotes = }} ''' '''SEAF''' is an international investment management group that provides growth capital and business assistance to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in emerging and transition markets underserved by traditional sources of capital.{{cite web|title=SEAF- Who we are|url=http://seaf.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=38&Itemid=68&lang=en}} == History == Founded in 1989 as the private equity investment subsidiary of the international development organization CARE, Small Enterprise Assistance Funds ("SEAF") evolved in 1995 into an independent organization specializing in the sponsorship and management of investment funds targeting growth-oriented, emerging enterprises located in countries underserved by traditional sources of capital.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} SEAF has managed or is managing 36 Funds across more than 30 countries with over USD 1 billion in aggregate committed capital, of which over USD 600 million has been invested through over 400 investments in SMEs, with more than 300 completed exits (through December 31, 2017). Investors in SEAF-sponsored funds represent a cross section of public and private institutions, including multilateral financial institutions, private foundations, pension funds, insurance companies, family offices, banks and other independent financial institutions.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} SEAF employs over 140 investment professionals worldwide within a network of 20+ regional offices. {{cite web |url=http://www.seaf.com/our_history.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808054627/http://www.seaf.com/our_history.htm |archivedate=2009-08-08 |df= }} SEAF History == SEAF International Funds == Below is a list of SEAF's active and historic funds and the countries in which they operate: === Global === * SEAF Flex Fund * SEAF SME Debt Facility * SEAF Global SME Fund === Central and Eastern European Funds http://serbia-montenegro.usaid.gov/code/navigate.php?Id=78 USAID's Description of SEAF's Work in Serbia and Montenegro === * Caresbac Polska (Closed) ** Poland * Baltics Small Equity Fund (Closed) ** Estonia ** Latvia ** Lithuania * SEAF Macedonia (Closed) * SEAF Macedonia II Fund * Central/Eastern Europe Growth Fund * SEAF Trans-Balkan Fund (Closed) ** Bulgaria through the Trans-Balkan Bulgaria Fund (Closed) ** Romania through the Trans-Balkan Romania Fund (Closed) ** Croatia through the SEAF Croatia (Closed) * SEAF South Balkan Fund ** Serbia ** Montenegro ** Macedonia * Georgia Regional Development Fund * SEAF Impact Serbia Fund * SEAF Caucasus Growth Fund ** Armenia ** Azerbaijan ** Georgia === Latin American Funds http://www.peru.com/finanzas/idocs2/2009/2/6/DetalleDocumento_541131.asp{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Peru.com Report on SEAF's Work in Peru (Spanish) === * SEAF Colombia Agribusiness Fund (Dual Fund Structure) * Trans-Andean Fund (Closed) ** Peru through the Fondo Transandino Peru Fund (Closed) ** Colombia through the Fondo Transandino Colombia Fund * Latam Growth Fund (Closed) * Latam Peru Fund (Closed) === Asian Funds https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123684535782705929 Wall Street Journal Report on SEAF's Work in Indiahttp://www.seaf.com/news/If%20you%20can%20take%20the%20heat,%20invest%20in%20Afghanistan%20%7C%20Reuters.com.pdf Reuters Report on SEAF's Work in Afghanistan === * Central Asia Small Enterprise Fund (Closed) ** Uzbekistan ** Kazakhstan ** Kyrgyz Republic ** Tajikistan ** Turkmenistan * Sichuan Small Investment Fund ** China * SEAF India Investment Growth Fund (Closed) * SEAF India Agribusiness Fund (Dual Fund Structure) *SEAF Bangladesh Ventures LLC * SEAF Blue Waters Growth Fund Limited ** Vietnam ** Cambodia * Afghan Growth Finance ** Afghanistan == Impact on Development == Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are often overlooked and therefore referred to as the "missing middle" in the developing world. Recent data results, analysis and case highlights (reports can be found below in the "Publications" section) demonstrate how SMEs can generate employment opportunities in their local communities, serve as links to regional and international markets for smaller local suppliers, and address market deficiencies and customer needs that would otherwise go unaddressed.{{cite web |url=http://www.seaf.com/Economic_Impact_Documents/From%20Poverty%20to%20Prosperity.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229004701/http://seaf.com/Economic_Impact_Documents/From%20Poverty%20to%20Prosperity.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-29 |df= }} SEAF Report on Development Impacthttp://www.brookings.edu/papers/2008/09_development_gibson.aspx Brookings Report on SMEs == SEAF and CEED == In 2006, the SEAF family grew larger with the creation of '''Center for Entrepreneurship and Executive Development (CEED)''', a legacy institution of [[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID) and SEAF, born out of USAID grant funding in SME equity investments made by SEAF throughout the Balkans, and EBRD in Slovenia. CEED centers provide business development training and technical assistance to entrepreneurs in emerging markets.{{cite web |url=http://www.ceed-global.org/web/default.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028114724/http://www.ceed-global.org/web/default.aspx |archivedate=2009-10-28 |df= }} CEED Homepagehttp://www.usaid.gov/locations/europe_eurasia/press/success/2006-03-22.html USAID CEED Article == Leadership == SEAF is led by a Corporate Board of Directors, an International Advisory Council, and a Management Team based in Washington, DC. The board and the council include business leaders, editors of periodicals, academics, and other international experts. Below is a list of senior management at SEAF:{{cite web |url=http://www.seaf.com/our_leadership.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808054710/http://www.seaf.com/our_leadership.htm |archivedate=2009-08-08 |df= }} SEAF Leadership === United States Headquarters === * '''[[Hubertus van der Vaart]], CEO'''
Bert van der Vaart is CEO and Co-Founder of SEAF. He has since been involved with the establishment and supervision of every SEAF fund, frequently traveling to collaborate with each SEAF fund office. Bert is a member of the SEAF Global Investment Committee * '''David Mathewson, President'''
David joined SEAF as President in 2016. Mr. Mathewson chairs SEAF’s Global Investment Committee and senior management team and supports the CEO in overseeing the strategic development and operations of SEAF. * '''Donald Lubreski, Treasurer and Chief Financial Officer'''
Don Lubreski serves as SEAF's Chief Financial Officer, providing financial oversight of the worldwide SEAF management entity and the private equity funds and other financing vehicles it manages. * '''Bob Webster, Managing Director'''
Bob Webster is Managing Director of Impact Investing Strategy at SEAF. He has a multi-faceted role, including a position on SEAF’s Global Investment Committee, ensuring that impact is embedded in every SEAF process, supporting new fund raises and launches, offering thought leadership to the impact investing space, and designing and implementing technical assistance components of SEAF funds. * '''Peter Righi, Global Director - CEED'''
Peter Righi is a co-developer and the Global Director of the Center for Entrepreneurship and Executive Development (CEED) program which was founded by the Small Enterprise Assistance Funds (SEAF) in 2006. * '''Robert Vodicka, Vice President'''
Robert’s primary focus is in fund formation and operational launch efforts. Robert is leading �SEAF’s tech deployment efforts, bringing developed technologies to SEAF markets and companies. Robert heads SEAF’s Environmental, Social and Governance efforts to ensure that all investees meet SEAF standards. Additional work includes due diligence on fund pipeline – market research, financial/operational analysis, valuation analysis, and investment structuring.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} === International Fund Managers === * '''Gary Dodge, Central and Eastern Europe'''
From its establishment in 1998 to its exit in 2010, Mr. Dodge managed SEAF's Baltics Small Equity Fund (BSEF), a private equity fund investing in small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the Baltic States. Under his direction, BSEF made equity investments into 23 Baltic companies and completed 22 exits. Since 2003, Mr. Dodge has also managed the SEAF Central and Eastern Europe Growth Fund (Growth Fund) together with Bert van der Vaart, SEAF's executive chairman. With Mr. Dodge's guidance, the Growth Fund made equity investments in nine companies in Croatia, Estonia, Poland and Romania, and completed five exits. * '''Armands Fomicevs, Georgia'''
Armands Fomicevs is the Managing Director of SEAF's Georgia Regional Development Fund (GRDF), where he supervised investments in ten companies across the Republic of Georgia. Mr. Fomicevs has worked for SEAF since 1998, when he served as the Principal Investment Officer for Latvia in SEAF's Baltic Small Equity Fund. * '''Nikola Stefanovic, Serbia, Macedonia, and Montenegro'''
Nikola Stefanovic has more than 10 years of direct investment experience. He currently serves as the Managing Director of the SEAF South Balkan Fund, a private equity fund focused on Serbia, Macedonia, and Montenegro. Furthermore, Mr. Stefanovic has served as a member of the Board of Directors for five of SEAF's portfolio companies (Finera Factoring, A2B Express Delivery, Gomex, PC Centar, and Logo Holding). * '''Piotr Kalaman, Poland'''
Piotr Kalaman joined SEAF in 1993 as an Investment Officer of CARESBAC-Polska. He was appointed Deputy Director for Investments in 1995 under Mr. van der Vaart's leadership and became Managing Director of the fund after Mr. van der Vaart's departure. While at SEAF, Mr. Kalaman has played a leading role in 30 investments and 15 exits. * '''George Zhang, China's Sichuan Province'''
George Zhang is a Managing Director of the SEAF Sichuan Small Investment Fund (SSIF), which invests in SMEs in China's Sichuan province. In this role, Mr. Zhang is responsible for originating, negotiating, executing and monitoring investment deals, and adding value to and structuring exits. In addition, Mr. Zhang provides technical assistance to SSIF portfolio companies, maintains relations with the government departments, manages the SSIF internal staff, and assists in fund marketing and communications. ==Notes and references== {{CCBYSASource|source=seaf.com|sourcepath=http://www.seafweb.org/our_history.htm|sourcearticle=Our history|revision=322730356}} {{reflist}} [[Category:Organizations related to small and medium-sized enterprises]]

'''Stockholm City Centre''' (''Stockholms innerstad'', ''Innerstaden'', ''Inre staden'') is the [[city centre]]{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} of [[Stockholm]] in [[Sweden]]. The entire city of Stockholm is also the centre of the [[Metropolitan Stockholm|Stockholm Metropolitan Area]]. Since 2007, Stockholm City Centre is organized into four ''stadsdelsområden'' (sometimes translated to [[Boroughs of Stockholm|boroughs]]): [[Kungsholmen (borough)|Kungsholmen]], [[Södermalm]], [[Norrmalm]] and [[Östermalm]].City of Stockholm: [http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ "Stockholm by districts"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218065732/http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ |date=December 18, 2008 }} Before 2007, Stockholm City Centre was organized into five boroughs: [[Katarina-Sofia borough]], [[Kungsholmen borough]], [[Maria-Gamla stan borough]], [[Norrmalm borough]] and [[Östermalm borough]]. The border between the historical [[Provinces of Sweden|provinces]] of [[Södermanland]] and [[Uppland]] splits Stockholm City Centre in two parts. 179,185 people live on an area of 28.05 km² in the northern (Uppland) part, which gives a density of 6,388.06/km².{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} The same data for the southern (Södermanland) part is 103,646 people on 7.44 km², giving a density of 13,930.91/km².{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} This border is purely historical and has no administrative significance whatsoever. {{wide image|Stockholm stadshuset.jpg|1800px|Stockholm City Centre}} ==Districts== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |+ Sortable table |-bgcolor=#dddddd ! {{Infobox person | name = Tevfik Arif | image = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Tofik Arifov | birth_date =May 1953"United States Public Records, 1970-2009," ([https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:23PT-5VR Tofik Arifov, Residence, Prt Washingtn, New York] | birth_place = [[Taraz|Dshambul]], [[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Turkey]] | nationality = | citizenship = Kazakh
Turkish | education = | occupation = Real estate developer, investor | employer = | organization = [[Bayrock Group]] | known_for = | home_town = | spouse = Gulnara Arifova | children = | awards = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Tofik Arifov''' ({{lang-ru|Тофик Арифов}}; born May 1953), also known as '''Tevfik Arif''', is a Soviet-born Turkish real estate developer and investor. He is the founder of the [[Bayrock Group]], a real estate development and investment company known for its business with [[Donald Trump]]. Bayrock and Trump were partners on the troubled [[Trump SoHo]] and the [[Trump International Hotel and Tower (Fort Lauderdale)|Trump International Hotel and Tower]] in [[Fort Lauderdale]], which was sold after it defaulted.{{cite news|last1=Behar|first1=Richard|title=Вся президентская рать. Кто стоит за Дональдом Трампом|url=http://www.forbes.ru/novosti-photogallery/330921-vsya-prezidentskaya-rat-kto-stoit-za-donaldom-trampom/photo/7?photo=7|accessdate=30 May 2017|work=Forbes|date=19 October 2016|language=ru}}{{cite news|last1=Burgis|first1=Tom|title=Dirty money: Trump and the Kazakh connection|url=https://www.ft.com/content/33285dfa-9231-11e6-8df8-d3778b55a923|accessdate=30 May 2017|work=Financial Times|date=19 October 2016}} ==Early life and career== Tevfik Arif was born Tofik Arifov in a [[Turks in Kazakhstan|Turkish family]] in [[Taraz|Dshambul]], [[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic]].{{cite news|last1=Shaw|first1=Craig|last2=Sentek|first2=Zeynep|title=The Football Leaks Family 1: World leaders, mobsters, smoke and mirrors|url=http://theblacksea.eu/index.php?idT=88&idC=88&idRec=1278&recType=story|work=The Black Sea|date=20 December 2016}} He received an international relations degree from a Moscow university. Prior to the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], Arif worked for the USSR's Ministry of Commerce and Trade for 17 years. He served as the deputy director of its Department of Hotel Management.{{cite news|last1=Kates|first1=Brian|last2=Schapiro|first2=Rich|title=Trump pal busted for allegedly running hooker ring on yacht|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/trump-pal-busted-allegedly-running-hooker-ring-yacht-article-1.191136|work=NY Daily News|date=1 October 2010}} Arif resigned from the ministry in 1991 and founded Speciality Chemicals Trading Company, an export-import business trading in rare metals, chrome, and raw materials. He then worked as an "agent on the ground" in Kazakhstan for [[Trans World Group]], a natural resources company run by [[David and Simon Reuben]]. Arif moved to Turkey in 1993. He had owned the Turkish jewellery business Alset Dis Ticaret since 1979. In 1999, Arif partnered with the [[Rixos Hotels|Rixos]] hotel chain to open the Labada luxury hotel in [[Antalya]], Turkey.{{cite news|last1=Strauss|first1=Delphine|title=Turkish police hold 10 in Atatürk yacht raid|url=https://www.ft.com/content/2448b03a-cd77-11df-9c82-00144feab49a|work=Financial Times|date=1 October 2010}} Following the independence of Kazakhstan, Arif and his brother secured ownership of ACCP, a [[chromium]] plant in [[Aktobe]] that had headquarters in the [[British Virgin Islands]].{{cite news|last1=Sorbello|first1=Paolo|title=Football Leaks: The Kazakh Connection|url=http://thediplomat.com/2017/01/football-leaks-the-kazakh-connection/|work=The Diplomat|date=3 January 2017}} The brothers developed ties to the "Kazakh Trio" — [[Alexander Mashkevitch]], [[Patokh Chodiev]], and [[Alijan Ibragimov]]. They later established offshore real estate companies to fund high-end developments in Kazakhstan, [[Azerbaijan]], and [[Turkey]]. ==Later career== ===Bayrock Group=== In 2001, Arif moved some of his businesses to the United States and founded the [[Bayrock Group]], a [[real estate development]] company. He began developing property in Brooklyn, first redeveloping Loehmann's Seaport Plaza, a waterfront shopping center in [[Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn|Sheepshead Bay]]. Arif was originally the sole employee of Bayrock, later hiring [[Felix Sater]] as managing director. After moving the Bayrock Group to [[Trump Tower]], Arif developed a relationship with billionaire businessman [[Donald Trump]]. Trump provided a licensing deal for the [[Trump SoHo]] hotel in a joint venture between the Bayrock Group and the [[Tamir Sapir|Sapir Organisation]]. In 2007, Bayrock traded future profits from Trump SoHo and other projects in exchange for $50 million in financing from Icelandic company [[FL Group]]. The arrangement led Bayrock's finance director to file racketeering lawsuits, alleging that money was diverted to people outside the company, including Salvatore Lauria, an associate of Sater's. Trump and Bayrock later developed the [[Trump International Hotel and Tower (Fort Lauderdale)|Trump International Hotel and Tower]] in Fort Lauderdale. Arif also worked to introduce Trump to investors from Russia.{{cite book|last1=Nance|first1=Malcolm|title=The Plot to Hack America: How Putin's Cyberspies and WikiLeaks Tried to Steal the 2016 Election|date=2016|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.|isbn=978-1-5107-2333-7|language=en}} Through Bayrock, Arif collaborated with Trump on projects in Turkey, Poland, Ukraine, Russia, Arizona, Colorado, New York, and Florida.{{cite news|last1=Silverman|first1=Gary|title=US election: Trump's Russian riddle|url=https://www.ft.com/content/549ddfaa-5fa5-11e6-b38c-7b39cbb1138a|work=Financial Times|date=14 August 2016}} Tevfik Arif, Arif Arif and their two brothers own [[Doyen Sports|Doyen Sports Investment]].{{cite news |url=https://theblacksea.eu/index.php?idT=88&idC=88&idRec=1277&recType=story |work=The Black Sea |date=December 21, 2016 |access-date=October 11, 2017 |title=Football Leaks: The Dirty Tricks of Doyen Sports}}{{cite web |url=http://www.elmundo.es/grafico/deportes/football-leaks/2016/12/17/585445ece2704e6a528b45ac.html |work=El Mundo |date=17 December 2016 |access-date=11 October 2017 |title=The Doyen Group}} ==Legal problems== In 2010, Arif was arrested in Turkey and charged with running a prostitution ring, accused of human trafficking from Russia and Ukraine. Arif was one of 10 people arrested aboard the $60 million yacht [[MV Savarona|MV ''Savarona'']] in a massive sting operation. The charges were eventually dropped.{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Kevin G.|title=A Canadian bankruptcy adds to Trump's legal woes|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article125541629.html|accessdate=30 May 2017|agency=McClatchy DC|date=20 January 2017|language=en}} ==Personal life== Arif is believed to live in Turkey. He owns a mansion in [[Port Washington, New York|Port Washington]].{{cite news|last1=Schreckinger|first1=Ben|title=The Happy-Go-Lucky Jewish Group That Connects Trump and Putin|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/04/the-happy-go-lucky-jewish-group-that-connects-trump-and-putin-215007|accessdate=April 11, 2017|work=Politico|date=April 9, 2017|quote=The Port Washington Chabad house has another Bayrock tie. Among its top 13 benefactors, its "Chai Circle," as listed on its website, is Sater's partner, Bayrock founder Tevfik Arif. Arif, a former Soviet bureaucrat turned wealthy real estate developer, owns a mansion in Port Washington, an upscale suburb, but he makes a curious patron for the town's Chabad. A Kazakh-born citizen of Turkey with a Muslim name, Arif is not Jewish, according to people who have worked with him.}} Although he is not Jewish, he is one of the largest donors to the [[Chabad]] of Port Washington. ==See also== *[[Timeline of investigations into Trump and Russia (2018)]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arif, Tevfik}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Port Washington, New York]] [[Category:Kazakhstani businesspeople]] [[Category:Kazakhstani emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Kazakhstani people of Turkish descent]] [[Category:Kazakhstani emigrants to Turkey]]

{{Infobox person | name = Touker Suleyman | image = File:Touker Suleyman.jpg | caption = Suleyman in 2015 | birth_name = Türker Süleyman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|8|4|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Famagusta]], Cyprus | occupation = Businessman, CEO - [[Hawes & Curtis]]/Ghost | residence = [[London]], England | networth = {{gain}} [[GBP|£]]150 million (2015) | children = 2 | nationality = | website = [http://www.toukersuleyman.com www.toukersuleyman.com] }}
'''Touker Suleyman''' (born '''Türker Süleyman''';<ref name=KP>{{cite news |last=|first=|date=20 March 2015 |title=Türker Süleyman Dragon’s Den’de|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/42/news/157918/PageName/www.magusa.org/www.magusa.org/festival|newspaper=Kıbrıs Postası|location= |access-date=21 March 2015}}</ref> 4 August 1953) is a multi-millionaire [[Turkish Cypriot]] [[United Kingdom|British]] business magnate fashion retail entrepreneur and investor. In 2001, his company Low Profile Group purchased UK shirt maker [[Hawes & Curtis]], and in 2008 he purchased UK fashion label [[Ghost (fashion brand)|Ghost]]. More recently, he has invested in a number of start-up companies including Bikesoup and Huxley & Cox.
In 2015, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' listed Suleyman as 637th in its Rich List, estimating his fortune to be in excess of £150 million.<ref>{{cite news |last=|first=|date=25 April 2015 |title=Rich List 2015: if you’re worth £100 million, join our club|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/Magazine/article1548974.ece|newspaper=The Sunday Times|location= |access-date=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=RT>{{cite news |last=|first=|date=12 July 2015 |title=Meet the new Dragons: Sarah Willingham, Touker Suleyman and Nick Jenkins|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-07-12/meet-the-new-dragons-sarah-willingham-touker-suleyman-and-nick-jenkins-2|newspaper=Radio Times|location= |access-date=21 March 2015}}</ref>
== Early life == Suleyman was born in [[Famagusta]] on 4 August 1953, into a [[Turkish Cypriot]] family.<ref name=ES200315>{{cite news |last=Blackhurst |first=Chris |date=20 March 2015 |title=Touker Suleyman: Dragon's role for clothing king who came back from a £20m burning |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/markets/touker-suleyman-dragons-role-for-clothing-king-who-came-back-from-a-20m-burning-10122795.html |newspaper=Evening Standard |location= |access-date=31 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=RW070808>{{cite news |last=Berwin |first=Lisa |date=7 August 2008 |title=Fashion addict |url=http://www.retail-week.com/fashion-addict/1792671.article |newspaper=Retail Week |location= |access-date=20 February 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://directors.findthecompany.co.uk/l/2072562/Mr-Touker-Suleyman |title=Mr. Touker Suleyman |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Find The Company |publisher= |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref> After moving to England, he attended Peckham Manor secondary school.<ref name=ES200315/>
== Career ==
=== Low Profile Group ===
In 1984, Suleyman acquired a small cash-and-carry business which subsequently became Low Profile Group, a clothing manufacturer supplying UK retail stores including [[Marks & Spencer]]. The company’s factories are based in [[Turkey]], [[Bulgaria]], and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].<ref name=ES200315/><ref name=T210114>{{cite news |last=Burn-Callander |first=Rebecca |date=21 Jan 2014 |title='X Factor for new firms’ founded by Ghost boss |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/10585249/X-Factor-for-new-firms-founded-by-Ghost-boss.html |newspaper=The Telegraph |location= |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref>
=== Hawes & Curtis ===
In 2001, Low Profile Group acquired Hawes & Curtis for £1.<ref name=FD251114>{{cite web |url=http://fdrecruit.co.uk/blog/general-news/interview-with-an-fd-sam-nesan |title=Interview with an FD; Sam Nesan |last1=Howarth |first1=Jo |last2= |first2= |date=25 November 2014 |website=FD Recruit |publisher= |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=T210114/> Turnover at Hawes & Curtis rose from £600,000 in 2001 to £30m in 2014, whilst Suleyman retained the Chairmanship of Hawes & Curtis. <ref name=FD251114/>
As of 2014, Hawes & Curtis operates from 30 branches in the UK and one in [[Cologne]], [[Germany]]. In 2013, [[UAE]] investment group Korath Holding signed a $5m deal to open 26 Hawes & Curtis stores across the [[Persian Gulf|Gulf]] over a period of five years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://retail-news.net/2013/08/13/british-shirtmaker-to-open-26-stores-across-gulf/ |title=British shirtmaker to open 26 stores across Gulf |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=13 August 2013 |website=Retail News|publisher= |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref>
=== Ghost ===
In 2008, Suleyman purchased UK fashion label [[Ghost (fashion brand)|Ghost]] after its owner, KCAJ, an [[Iceland]]ic investment fund, cut investment following the collapse of the [[2008–11 Icelandic financial crisis|Icelandic banking market]].<ref name=I311008>{{cite news |last=O’Brien |first=Rachel |date=31 October 2008 |title=Businessman saves fashion label Ghost from collapse |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/news/businessman-saves-fashion-label-ghost-from-collapse-981380.html |newspaper=The Independent |location= |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref> The acquisition safeguarded 142 jobs across the company.<ref name=I311008/> In 2009 the label announced its first collaboration with design duo Modernist.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Modernist unveils new Ghost story |url=http://www.drapersonline.com/news/womenswear/news/modernist-unveils-new-ghost-story/5004247.article|newspaper=Drapers |location= |date=11 July 2009 |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref>
=== Other investments ===
Alongside Ghost, Touker Suleyman has invested in Docks Rio, a casual boat shoe brand; Intelligent Futures, an online advertising start-up; Huxley & Cox, a manufacturer of luxury handbags; and Bikesoup, an online marketplace for bicycles in which he invested £100,000 for an undisclosed stake.<ref name=T210114/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://companycheck.co.uk/director/905943145 |title=Touker Suleyman |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Company Check |publisher= |access-date=20 February 2015}}</ref>
===''Dragons' Den''=== {{main|Dragons' Den (UK TV series)|l1=Dragons' Den}} In 2015, Suleyman was chosen to join the investors' panel on the thirteenth series of [[BBC]] television programme ''[[Dragons' Den (UK TV series)|Dragons' Den]]'', alongside [[Nick Jenkins]] and [[Sarah Willingham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/31933804/dragons-den-hires-three-new-er-dragons-for-new-series |title=Dragons' Den hires three new, er dragons for new series |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=17 March 2015 |website=BBC |publisher= |access-date=31 March 2015}}</ref>
== Personal life == Suleyman lives in [[London]] and has two daughters.<ref name=RT/><ref name=RW070808/>

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Woolworths Holdings Limited | logo = [[File:Woolworths SA logo.jpg|frameless]] | image = | image_caption = | type = Corporation | founder = [[Max Sonnenberg]] | area_served = South Africa
Mauritius | key_people = Ian Moir (CEO)
Simon Susman ([[Chairman|Non-executive chairman]]) | industry = Retailing | products = Clothing, footwear, accessories, groceries, beauty products, homeware and financial services. | revenue = {{profit}} [[South African rand|R]]75.2 Billion (2018){{cite web | url=http://www.woolworthsholdings.co.za/investor/annual_reports/ar2015/whl_2015_afs1.pdf | title=Woolworths Annual Report 2015 | publisher=Woolworths Holdings Limited | date=2015 | accessdate=5 December 2015}} | operating_income = {{profit}} [[South African rand|R]]5.59 Billion (2015) | net_income = {{profit}} [[South African rand|R]]3.12 Billion (2015) | num_employees = 18,563 (South Africa only) | parent = | divisions = Woolworths (Proprietary) Limited
[[Country Road]] (Australia)
[[David Jones Limited|David Jones]] (Australia)
Woolworths Financial Services | homepage = {{URL|http://www.woolworthsholdings.co.za}}
{{URL|woolworths.co.za}} | foundation = 1931 | location = 93 Longmarket Street, [[Cape Town]], South Africa | caption = }} [[File:Woolies Somerset Mall.jpg|thumb|Woolworths store in [[Somerset Mall (South Africa)|Somerset Mall]], showing the current branding.]] [[File:Woolworths Johannesburg.jpg|thumb|Woolworths food store in [[Johannesburg]], showing the old branding.]] '''Woolworths Holdings Limited''' ({{jse|WHL}}) is a South Africa-based multinational retail company that owns the South African retail chain Woolworths, and Australian retailers [[David Jones Limited|David Jones]] and [[Country Road]] Group. Woolworths, however, has no association to Australia's [[Woolworths Supermarkets|Woolworths]] supermarket chain. The first Woolworths store opened in [[The Old Royal Hotel]] in Plein Street, [[Cape Town]] in October 1931. It was founded by [[Max Sonnenberg]] assisted by his son Richard and Fred Kossuth. The business was later modelled on [[Marks & Spencer]] of the United Kingdom.David B. Yoffie (7 October 1997). [http://harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu/relay.jhtml?name=itemdetail&id=798026 "Higher Education"] Harvard Business Publishing The relationship was formed after the Second World War, which led to Marks & Spencer making an investment Woolworths in 1947. These shares were later sold, but close ties still remain.{{Cite news|url=http://moneyweb.co.za/mw/view/mw/en/page295164?oid=534710&sn=2009+Detail&pid=287226|title=Enabling all Africans to invest in stock markets|date=2017-05-04|work=Moneyweb|access-date=2017-08-30|language=en-US}} The South African Woolworths business consists of full-line fashion, home and beauty stores, many of which incorporate a premium food retail offering. Stand-alone food stores and "Food Stops" attached to [[Engen Petroleum|Engen]] petrol stations are also located in urban areas. Woolworths operates 217 full line stores and 421 food stand alone stores in South Africa, with 65 stores throughout the rest of Africa. Woolworths sells clothing and accessory items under a number of premium brands, namely Studio W, RE: and Edition, with the Group’s Australian brands [[Country Road]], [[Witchery (company)|Witchery]] and Trenery also represented. ==History== Founded by Max Sonnenberg and his son Richard, Woolworths South Africa first opened its doors on 30 October 1931 in Plein Street Cape Town, in what had been the stately dining room of the famous Royal Hotel. While Sonnenberg had no affiliation with any of the other Woolworths-named companies anywhere else in the world, his plan was to develop a chain of stores based on the American retailer, F.W. Woolworth Company which operated stores in the United States of America and in the United Kingdom. A pivotal point in Woolworths' history came after World War II, when the company established its relationship with Marks & Spencer (M&S). Sonnenberg and Sir [[Simon Marks, 1st Baron Marks of Broughton|Simon Marks]], son of the M&S founder, became good friends which led to M&S buying shares in Woolworths in 1947. Later, David Susman, son of Max Sonnenberg's business partner Elie Susman, married Ann Laski, Lord Marks' niece. David Susman became a non-executive director of M&S, a position he held for nearly 30 years. Although M&S ultimately sold its shares of Woolworths, the two companies maintain close ties to this day. Woolworths merged with [[Truworths]] in 1981 to form the Wooltru Group. Over a twenty-year relationship the company underwent much change and transformation, before it was unbundled from the group in 1997. In 1998, the company bought a controlling interest in Australian clothing retailer [[Country Road]]. Simon Susman, David's son, became Chief Executive of Woolworths in 2000.{{Cite web|url=http://m.news24.com/fin24/Companies/Retail/Woolworths-CEO-resigns-20101118|title=Woolworths' CEO resigns|website=m.news24.com|access-date=2017-08-30}} David Susman died on 11 May 2010 at the age of 84. Simon Susman retired from his post as CEO at the end of 2010 replaced by Ian Moir, formerly the CEO of the Group’s Country Road Group subsidiary. In 2014, Woolworths acquired Australian department store [[David Jones Limited|David Jones]] for $2.15 billion.{{cite web|url=http://www.asx.com.au/asx/statistics/displayAnnouncement.do?display=pdf&idsId=01507869|title=Myer response to David Jones announcement|date=9 April 2014|publisher=ASX-Media-Release, Australia|accessdate=15 April 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asx.com.au/asx/statistics/displayAnnouncement.do?display=pdf&idsId=01507792|title=David Jones Board Recommends A$4.00 Cash per Share Proposal|date=9 April 2014|publisher=ASX-Media-Release, Australia|accessdate=15 April 2014}} with [[Country Road]] CEO Iain Nairn succeeding Paul Zahra as chief executive.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/iain-nairn-to-head-david-jones-as-paul-zahra-quits/story-e6frg8zx-1227021431207|title=Iain Nairn to head David Jones as Paul Zahra quits|date=12 August 2014|publisher=News Corp Australia|agency=The Australian|last1=Speedy|first1=Blair|accessdate=12 August 2014}} Following the takeover, Woolworths sold the iconic 1938 Market Street store. ==Controversy== ===Christian magazines=== In October 2010, Woolworths came under fire as they opted to remove Christian magazines from their shelves and discontinue their sale. This was met with a huge outcry from the Christian community, many voicing that they would boycott the chain store.{{Cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Woolies-bans-Christian-mags-20101020|title=Woolworths bans Christian mags|work=News24|access-date=2017-09-03}} Woolworths maintained it was strictly a business decision, with CEO Simon Susman attributing their decision to diminishing number of sales. Woolworths returned the five magazines to its shelves following a public outcry.[http://www.timeslive.co.za/business/article718396.ece/Woolworths-repents Woolworths repents – ''Times'' LIVE] ===Soft drink imitation=== In early 2012 the South African Advertising Standards Authority ruled that Woolworths' vintage cold drink range was an imitation of [[Frankie's (soft drink)|Frankie's Soft Drinks]] range. It was ruled that Woolworths intentionally copied the phrase "Good Old Fashioned Soft Drinks" to promote its own line of beverages thereby infringing on the rights of Frankie's Soft Drinks. Woolworths agreed to remove the range immediately.{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/news/woolworths-to-remove-entire-soft-drinks-range-1.1225944#.T8969NXar_g | title=Woolworths to remove entire soft drinks range | publisher=iol | date=2 February 2012 | accessdate=6 June 2012 | author=Peters, Sherlissa}} After the event Woolworths South Africa's CEO Ian Moir publicly stated that "Public opinion is so much against us and, whether we're right or whether we're wrong, customer opinion is against us."{{cite web | url=http://dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-02-01-frankies-vs-woolworths-good-old-fashioned-david-and-goliath-battle | title=Frankie's vs. Woolworths: Good old-fashioned David-and-Goliath battle | publisher=Daily Maverick | date=1 February 2012 | accessdate=6 June 2012 | author=Nicolson, Greg}} ===Affirmative action=== {{See also|Black Economic Empowerment}} In September 2012 Woolworths was accused of racism by some groups for allegedly discriminating against [[White South African|white]] job applicants and staff. The accusations followed after claims that the retailer's advertising on their career site said its jobs are only open to "African, Coloured and Indian" candidates.{{cite news|title=Woolworths douses racial fires|url=http://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/Woolworths-douses-racial-fires-20120904|accessdate=14 January 2013|date=4 September 2012|author=Fadia Salie|agency=News 24}} Shortly after the incident, Woolworths changed the advert text to say "In accordance with Woolworths' Employment Equity approach, preference will be given to candidates from designated groups".{{cite web|title=Racist Woolworths SA defiant|url=http://www.sapromo.com/features/item/310-racist-woolworths-sa-defiant|publisher=[[SA Promo]]|accessdate=14 January 2013|author=Peter Church|date=3 September 2012}} ===Plagiarism=== In October 2013 rumours of plagiarism surfaced when Euodia Roets, a South African artist, accused Woolworths of using her designs that were kept as samples after contract negotiations failed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.groundup.org.za/article/copyright-credit-woolworths-and-hummingbird/|title=Copyright, credit, Woolworths and the hummingbird|last=Pedeboy|first=Delphine|date=21 October 2013|website=|publisher=[[Ground Up]]|access-date=26 July 2016}} In her article Euodia Roets shows illustrative images of her design and compares it to a cushion later sold by Woolworths on which a strikingly similar design was used. Woolworths denied these allegations on their website.[http://www.woolworths.co.za/store/fragments/corporate/corporate-index.jsp?content=corporate-content&contentId=cmp200788] Cushion Design Allegation In her allegations Euodia Roets also claimed "If that text is in fact from Wikipedia, Wiki requires attribution on all commercial use of their text. You'd be correct in assuming Woolies did no such thing.". The text used on the design is an exact match of portions of text lifted from Wikipedia's [[Hummingbird]] article, without attribution, in violation of its [[Creative Commons License]]. When pressed on the matter, the official Woolworths South Africa Twitter account opined that "We've checked with our lawyer; Wikipedia does not own the content."{{cite web|title=Woolworths South Africa Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/WOOLWORTHS_SA/status/392632794993926144|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=22 October 2013}} ==See also== *[[List of Woolworth divisions and namesakes]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Department stores of South Africa]] [[Category:Supermarkets of South Africa]] [[Category:Companies based in Cape Town]] [[Category:Retail companies of South Africa]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1931]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange]] [[Category:South African brands]] [[Category:Companies of South Africa]]
